As ascetic as you'd expect of a film depicting country in the Soviet Communist orbit, yet featuring a young woman who in just a week's time finds her life brightening for the first time.
An original, a war movie like none you've seen before--about a pair of twin boys who imitate the behavior of the cruel adults they see during the German occupation of Hungary.
In Shawn Levy's hands, the predictably grueling Jewish custom of sitting shiva becomes the occasion of comedy and high family drama.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A pleasant enough look at how a merry-go-roundelay leads three people to have fits of jealousy.
A Hallmark greeting card of a movie that will be loved by the sentimental folks in the audience and grudgingly appreciated by others.
Effective Hitchcockian suspense
Chadwick Boseman disappears into his character in a great performance but the film is ill-served by a confusing non-linear design.
Confused plot, accents difficult to understand.
Scott Haze's frightening performance propels this tale of necrophilia.
Features Brendan Gleeson's towering performance as a good priest who is dismayed to find his entire small-town parish alienated.
Part common gangster tale and part kaleidoscopic flight of sci-fi fancy, this model of female empowerment fits in with Luc Besson's history of creating strong women characters.
Same absurd premise, same insipid dialogue.
Intermittently funny but not without a share of forced comedy.
A delightful comedy about a woman with a profession to die for but who would almost gladly give up the endless plush hotels if the right man came along.
Imaginative sci-fi tale with a metaphysical dimension.
Curiously tense throughout despite a paucity of physical action.
If you're looking to take a "trip" but shun chemical agents, this partly animated journey into another dimension may be for you.
Rest easy, America. The Guest can take on ISIL single-handedly--after entertaining the terrorist army with a clever script.
Overlong with a labyrinthine plot but Liam Neeson's performance makes viewing worthwhile.
Tense psychological thriller centering on a rivalry between a husband and the man to whom his wife is attracted.
Three-inch heels? Not for this woman, who trekked 1,000 humorless miles.
Cool
Timothy Spall's impressive performance as the 19th Century English artist notwithstanding, this is a film to respect more than to love.
Light, predictable comedy.
Well researched doc on Public Enemy #1, the head of the Sinaloa cartel whose location may have been known for a long time by authorities.
movie_title: Drug Lord: The Legend Of Shorty (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Comes across as an authentic view of the Old West as opposed to the usual Cowboys-and-Indians melodramas.
This parody of Italian politics did not travel well across the Atlantic. I'll stick to the likes of "Thank You for Smoking" and "Dave."
Daniel Radcliffe anchors a scary, amusing movie.
An unrecognizable Steve Carell is awesome in a deadly serious, humorless role as heir to the Du Pont fortune, whose hobby is training a wrestling team for the 1988 Olympics.
Believe it or not, even world class scientists have private lives.
A charming slacker promenades about Berlin streets.
A generic, plodding story.
Women are protective; men are cowards. Here's evidence of that, delivered with the excitement of an avalanche in a hip French resort.
While hardly a riveting spy story, this documentary reveals much of whistleblower Edward Snowden's character while warning of a dangerous loss of civil liberties in America.
A technically brilliant animated interpretation of Japanese oldest recorded legend.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Credible narrative focusing on a female guard at Gitmo and an intelligent Arab prisoner who gets under her skin and changes her from a tough soldier to a softer and more understanding American.
Though characters are stereotypes, action scenes are terrifying.
Effectively combines a John Grisham-type small-town trial with a father-son reconciliation weepie.
The year's best pic to date is anchored by a bold performance from J.K. Simmons as a sadistic teacher of jazz.
With intriguing use of animation, this doc reminds us that pirates may be ordinary citizens struggling to make a living.
Involving coming-of-age drama disguised as a psychological thriller.
An inspirational, feel-good drama about the Lost Boys of Sudan who make good as refugees in America and change the lives of Americans in close contact with them.
We're regularly advised that marriage is work, but the work should not be as hard as that faced by one couple in a riveting movie adapted by the novelist and directed by David Fincher.
Stephen King's tense psychological thriller asks the question, What would you do if you discovered that your husband is a serial killer?
Particularly intriguing is that this is not a who dunnit but a what-done-what. A crime is committed, but we don't know even what the crime is until considerably into the picture.

Communication problems have always been with us, and writer-director Jason Reitman's low-key, character-driven movie about an ensemble of suburban families is a stunning look at how the Internet has added another barrier between parents and teens.
A feel-good movie with crackerjack ensemble acting that captures a victory over bigotry in the UK of 1985.
Delightful comedy about two elderly gents who renew their friendship during a trip to Iceland.
Evoking forced comic starts, this movie about a group of suicidal people who bond with one another strives for Hallmark sentimentality but fails even at that.
An authentic look at an aging gay couple and the tensions created when, because of financial difficulties, they have to move in with friends and relatives.
Elaborately produced sci-fi that takes place almost completely within the last train out of anywhere.
Plagiarist Jayson Blair takes up too much of the doc's time given his unflattering, close-up appearance and compulsive use of "um" and "you know."
movie_title: A Fragile Trust: Plagiarism, Power And Jayson Blair At The New York Times (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The great documentarian Errol Morris did not have to work too hard to satirize Rumsfeld.
All of Chavez's charisma comes through.
Britain's funniest comedian proves adept at physical humor as well as verbal in a film based on a fictional character shown in Brit media.
A rollicking crime story filled with humor, pathos and stupidity.
Graphic scenes notwithstanding, Lars von Trier is most interested in probing the character of Joe, just a gal who can't say no.
Poignant and funny tale of a bully victim's revenge.
Sam Rockwell proves to be one of the funniest actors in the business.
A well-meaning but uninspiring documentary lobbying for treatment, not incarceration, for addicts
A penetrating doc about a photographer who became a celebrity only after her death.
An original enough idea: that a pianist will be killed if he fails to play a piece without a single mistake.
Entertaining fable with dazzling effects opining that there is good in every human being
Patriotism, pride, and fireworks trump psychological character development, and that's not a bad thing.
An intense study of a woman whose faith in her job assisting suicide erodes.
A poignant tale of an unlikely romance in India.
This film feeds our outrage--that a judge has the chutzpah to send kids up the river for minor offenses in return for kickbacks.
It's inspiring to watch a 61-year-old action star "break a leg" and a neck equally well in one of the best thrillers in years.
An intimate drama with comic undertones that subtly exhibits a long-term marriage with fissures.
A wonderfully animated fantasy based on the actual life of the designer of the Japanese Zero aircraft.
Captures the exuberance of adolescents.
Neither the banal conversations of the monuments men nor the widespread activities of the group make for riveting entertainment.
Yet another reinvention of the vampire legend, this slowly-paced romance tries to show that love can last for an eternity, but the film itself will seem that way for those who are not Jarmusch fans.
The identity crisis could have been more convincing if Zoe Kazan had Zoe Deschanel's charm.
A taut Palestinian thriller with romantic overtones that finds itself as a finalist for the Best Foreign Film Academy Award
A doc that is even more interested in the nature of a modern man's obsession than in the paintings of Johannes Vermeer.
This "different" and "original" minimalist drama (no music soundtrack, only one scene exhibited) is a meditation on passionate love and violent death among a small group of French homosexuals.
A brisk documentary happily without talking heads about bikers in an inner-city Baltimore 'hood.
Delightful French fluff.
Elle Fanning is so good that she is on her way to becoming the next Tilda Swinton--the title character of Sally Potter's great film 'Orlando.'
The principal character's conversations are so flabby that you cannot be blamed for wanting to avoid him.
Foodies will be disappointed as the shaking camera superficially gazes at the cuisine while emphasizing annoying characters.
A mostly two-hander whose minimalism becomes tedious.
Paul Rudd and Amy Poehler have a ball skewering the conventions of romantic comedy.
Entertaining, often emotional look at the life of America's most popular film critic.
Bracing drama with music based on the Broadway Tony-Award winning show.
Relying on the emergency room to treat illness is no way to live, says this doc which serves as a wake-up call.
A respectful dramatization of a turning point in modern Swedish history, as a newspaper editor risks plunging his country into war over columns trashing the Nazis.
Anarchy unleashed. Never dull.
Recycled myths
If you still don't believe that money drives American politics...
Chilling tale of brainwashing that summons up the Jonestown Massacre.
Slow moving and thoughtful, a character-driven look at an act of eco-terrorism gone wrong.
The year's most delightful comedy to date may even restore your faith in doctors.
If you're curious about why a terrorist would work for the Israeli government, look no further.
A painfully melodramatic, over-the-top comedy-drama without subtlety, effective humor, or credibility.
Fairly intriguing romance aside, this is a clever examination of the role taken by words on the one hand and pictures on the other.

A look at three middle-school aged kids ostracized by their peers for being non-conforming, punk band aspirants. Well acted by the young trio but they are simply not interesting enough to rivet my attention.
This entertaining narrative is probably a realistic view of what high-school life is like for privileged Californians.
Stop the presses! In this well-edited doc, Katie Couric tells us to pass on the soda and consume lots of whole grains, fruits and veggies!
A fresh look at the subgenre of musical horror show, a promising entry from freshman director Jerome Sable.
A nightmarish tale with considerable comic undertones about a nebbish who imagines life as a bon vivant.

A stunning piece of historical fiction conveying the spirit of its times with a riveting performance by its principal actress in the role of a woman too low in status to dine with the aristocracy and too high to sup with the servants.
An unappealing, laugh-free sit-com.
An intriguing narrative based on the doings of the evil Nazi, Dr. Mengele, who hides from the authorities in Argentina and is determined to continue his grotesque experiments.
A sumptuous production about a courtesan and a young man who tries to win her away from a rich count.
A privileged and beautiful young woman and her African friend do good in Tanzania and determine that experiences are more important than things.
A failed attempt at cinematic minimalism.
A heartbreaking tale of migrants from Central America who risk their lives to cross into the U.S., some dying annually in the Arizona desert.
Imagine Woody Allen as a pimp and John Turturro as a stud, and then imagine that the Allen-Turturro team makes it work.
Standard-issue revenge melodrama.
A psychological thriller/cum horror tale about a dangerous fellow with three personalities, a movie that proves Robert Louis Stevenson right: two are fine, more's a crowd.
The incredible but true story of a Jewish family that hid from the Nazis in a cave for 511 days, done as a hybrid of documentary and narrative.
A French comedy-drama with the light, Gallic touch that is rarely found in American rom-coms.
One of the finer character studies of a man who has dedicated his life for twenty years to getting revenge
The documentarians make a good case that anyone can be redeemed, even a zonked out, washed up heavy metal singer.
A delightful tale wonderfully animated
A solid noir tale with heavy comic touches
The house of Universal plays it safe with formulaic mayhem.
Fans of Buster Keaton and Jacques Tati may eat this up: others (like me) will find the whimsy repetitive.
Though static, this Albanian film features exceptional acting by non-professionals.
Overly sedate look at a woman's poor adjustment to civilian life upon her return from a war.
Corny but more effective than a poster pleading 'Save the whales!'
Corny banter distracts from tension in this implausible thriller.
Woody Harrelson's awards-worthy performance is the only reason to see this police drama.
Director Cedar finds universal truths about father-son rivalries in his satiric look at professorial infighting.
Sentimental tale of how man's best friend remains so even after the former's death.
'Larger Than Life' proves an apt subtitle.
A chilling Alaskan tale that makes us wonder: Where is Sarah Palin when we finally need her?
A convoluted caper chock full of holes.
Predictably hokum but embracing performers who are having a grand time.
A stunning film about the banality of evil from captured archival shots taken in Nazi Germany.
Dennis Quaid tries to look villainous but he's no Jack Nicholson
A superb blend of tears and comedy.
Though not original this ghost story is worth seeing for Sara Paxton's terrific performance
Everyone with the exception of the bureaucratic inspector emerges likable as do all of the good-natured animals.
Tepid, exhausting-overlong tale of sexual awakening adapted from a popular novel.
Exquisitely crafted, curiously uninvolving.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Gorgeous photography, schmaltzy story
Don't worry about the convuluted plot: see it for a kickass performance by women's martial arts champ Gina Carano.
A wistful, charming, naturalistic tale evoking the fantasies of a 60-year-old citizen of Rome.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Rachel Weisz's stirring performance allows us in the audience to feel her character's heartbreak
The title character's charm cannot make up for the film's lack of a narrative center
A somber but humorous look at how women in one Lebanese town helped to end fighting there.
A boundary-breaking documentary about the world's oldest profession as seen in three cities.
As a French romantic drama about the effect of long absence on love, this displays neither the wit nor the acting chops of (for example) 'Before Sunrise.'
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Marvelous story of a crackerjack sub teacher with problems greater than those of his class.
A fast-paced, original police drama with snappy dialogue is marred only by subtitles often difficult to read.
A screwball comedy with some wonderful originality.
Guy Pearce's one-liners cannot save this videogame.
Deeply religious lad attends party-loving secular college with intriguing, mixed results
Seann William Scott is the funniest movie comic of his generation, enlivening an otherwise copycat sequel.
An evenly balanced doc about Israel's noble, socialist experiment: the kibbutz
movie_title: Inventing Our Life: The Kibbutz Experiment (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Terminally quirkly well beyond its expiration minutes.
An attractive cast act out a story of kidnapping and adultery under TV-style directing.
movie_title: Woman Thou Art Loosed: On the 7th Day (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Features the kind of whimsy that would appeal largely to a hip young audience.
Gratuitous scenes of student prostitution do little to embellish a bourgeois Paris wife's identity crisis.
We've heard it before: 'Consume less,' but we need to have our memories refreshed often by docs like this.
Stephen Dorff's energetic performance cannot compensate for the minimalism of the plot.
A tension-filled dramatization of the actual hijacking of a French airbus in December 1994.
An energetic fantasy that favors capital punishment for all of our society's vulgarities.
An often hilarious comedy filled with vulgar dialogue, slapstick antics, and great chemistry between the principals.
A sedate but riveting look at neurosis on both sides of teacher's desk.
Will Ferrell speaks fluent Spanish, but with dialogue like this, what's the point?
Guy Pearce in a great Charles Bronson imitation in this revenge fantasy.
A heartbreaking story of an 11-year-old deserted by his dad.
Though toothless as satire the movie is a light,elegant, even credible romantic comedy
Michael Knowles directs with all the complexity of a TV sitcom.
Not even the great Michel Piccoli can save a film with little bite but too much forced humor
If this party were to take place in Damascus, Assad would run for his life.
Though repetitious, this photographed play is brutal, witty, funny and scary.
Diane Keaton's frequent bouts of hysteria are numbing in this otherwise amiable shaggy dog story.
A poor man's Fatal Attraction.
Who'd have guessed that a silent movie would be the favorite for year-end awards?
A disaster movie without tension or humor.
The story is involving but the character are types rather than authentic individuals.
This indie is all about ambiguity and is anchored by Michael Shannon's awards-worthy performance.
A moving, suspenseful, exquisitely photographed look at an insane surgeon's activities.
Strong performances keep the film involving despite its pedestrian, workmanlike production.
Bolivia never looked better, but doesn't a film about outlaws deserve a faster pace?
Fast, fun, raunchy.
If this isn't one of the funniest horror pics ever made, I've got to get out more often.
Iranian fundamentalist vs. freedom-seeking sister in this ferocious battle of religious wills.
It's always good to watch Katie Holmes, but she can't scare me.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Vera Farmiga is as great a director as she is an actress in this tale of a fundamental Christian who has doubts.
The backstabbing endemic in office politics becomes exquisitely literal.
A staid documentary about teaching below the college level marred by incessant, unnecessary music in the soundtrack and by conventional direction.
A pro-Georgian, anti-Russian war movie with lots of action.
The #1 best-seller is brought lovingly to screen.
Not many battles but good character exploration surrounding the war between the Philippines and the U.S. 1899-1902.
A humorless fictionalized look at Mozart's sister, played adagio almost throughout where some allegro vivace would have been in order.
Some good one-line zingers but relies too heavily on visual and vocal vulgarity.
Involving tale of people on the cust of adulthood who get their kicks from firebombing targets while awaiting Armageddon.
Rigorously dramatizes the tension between a father and his transgendered son.
Stunning expose of a scandal indicating that UN personnel assigned to stop the Bosnian sex trade indulged in the corruption themselves.
Cut the wise-beyond-his-years small fry and you've got a decent adult comedy.
A reasonably involving, noirish look at a Czech couple during the German occupation of their country.
The picture tries to fuse western and sci-fi genres but the sci-fi aspect is generic and weaker than the former.
Don Cheadle is Brendan Gleeson's ideal fish-out-of-water foil.
Yet another superhero pic but one nicely rooted in history.
A stunning, surprisingly credible marriage of acting, story, and effects.
Gus Van Sant sells out to Hallmark
A warm, amusing British memoir.
Suspend disbelief and you'll enjoy this fluffy comedy of manners.
Fassbender's graphic performance sheds light on sex addiction in this NC-17 film
A family drama whose distinction comes primarily from its nuances and subtleties.
Has sexy Freudian and Jungian dialogue.
There's little here to tickle the funny bone.
Intriguing look at a double agent during World War 2 who some say "saved the world."
Exquisitely photographed gunplay barely makes up for a confusing plot.
A touching German romance that blows American rom-coms out of the water.
Hard-hitting doc takes aim against the lies of the tobacco industry.
A harrowing story of a Polish Catholic who develops empathy for the Jews he saved during WWII.
Cute father-daughter chemistry but nothing out of the ordinary.
People fawn over a pretentious Buddhist.
A solid, workmanlike look at a profession (piano technician) never before covered in the cinema.
Herzog does not convince us that the death sentence is barbaric but he does elicit provocative testimony from his subjects.
An imaginative psychological study of a woman torn between two ways of life.
A competent film but only marginally better than typical TV fare.
Stunning photography compensates for silly plot.
Predictable plot, solid music and dancing.
Director Darryl Roberts evokes heartfelt responses about America's obsession with dieting.
movie_title: America The Beautiful 2: The Thin Commandments (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's no better film this year that illustrates the idea that what's important is the journey, not the destination.
Though stagey, the film incisively explores a crisis in a financial house.
An engrossing, zinger-full dramatization of backroom Presidential politics.
The Finnish director uses deadpan humor to evoke both the silliness and the good will of people.
A solid Iranian Oscar-entry that puts women in the forefront in a battle of wills that happily posits more questions than answers.
Kids will love it and their parents might shed a tear or two of joy.
A baseball movie whose intelligence takes us backstage to hear sometimes electric conversations among the business people involved in America's great pastime.
An intellectual exercise lacking in tension.

Le Guay's film is a frothy entertainment, nothing much that smacks of "art," but is rather one which can appeal to a variety of audiences that can relate to French movies that are not endless talk-fests.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e √©tage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You don't go to this movie for the story but rather for Streep's searing performance.
Schmaltzy, sure, but this witty comedy-drama is a riot of colors and blessed by performances from A-list British actors.
Jack Black out of character in a semi-serious role. He's good!
The theme seems to be 'a man's redemption,' but this is merely an excuse for little more than a filmed shooting gallery.
Aside from a top performance from Helen Mirren as Hitchcock's wife, the film is particularly intriguing for the way it shows the impact of a director's private life on his work.
Though static--the talking is the action--this is a worthy addition to cinematic biopics, one featuring an Oscar-worthy role from Daniel Day-Lewis.
A series that gloried in wit, irony and sex has been reduced to a generic spy thriller.
Who needs the fake fires and explosions of the"Terminator" series when you can see the real thing in this doc?
Few docs can equal this one as an illustration of the aphorism 'Justice delayed is justice denied.'
An intelligent person's psychological thriller, as suspense filled as some of Hitchcock's output.
A tender, lovely story about a man condemned by polio to live in an iron lung who wishes at age thirty-eight to lose his virginity.
Acting and soundtrack are spot-on but the frequent jump-cuts and lack of a compelling comparison between families work against the film's success.
Seemlessly blends a love affair with political struggles while stickling closely to actual historical events in Denmark in the mid-18th Century.
A slow-moving, minimalist film with gorgeous photography which features a sudden event, a coup de theatre, that could end a romantic relationship
A superbly edited doc about an unusual relationship between a Jewish woman and a German SS officer.
A delightful, albeit partly dark look at how World War II affected a band of merry schoolchildren in a rural village in France.
movie_title: La nouvelle guerre des boutons (War of the Buttons) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While the movie follows the rom-com template overall, the awards-worthy acting of the two principals and the hyper pace of the action make this a must-see.
It's too conventional to be another 'Best Exotic Marigold Hotel' but features light touches of Gallic comedy and the right degree of sentiment.
Technically astonishing albeit with a narrative that finds coherence not something difficult to achieve but basically irrelevant.
A fast-paced, often hilarious pic about a woman who choose a gay friend to make her pregnant.
A respectful look at a colorful painter in Brazil's most colorful city, Salvador.
Insightful look at how a young woman serves as a catalyst for sexual mayhem within an L.A. family unit.
The director's semi-autobiographical reflections on youthful protest movements in France 1968-71 are filled with much talk, insufficient action.
Though a bold rethinking of the British classic, the film is marred by muddled dialogue and dark and claustrophobic photography.
Excels as both a social critique and a poignant tale of emotional vulnerability.
Tim Roth turns in a momentous performance as a detective in a movie showing that billionaires do not always have it made.
Powerfully and with comic undertones, this movie delivers the message 'You can't go home again.'
As a police drama and especially as a multi-cultural buddy movie, 'End of Watch' makes for exciting fare.
The oft-used theme of babies switched at birth gets a solid, politicized treatment in this French-Israeli production.
Who knew that this satire of small-town culture would be the year's funniest satire to date?
What makes this picture special is that the thriller aspect, tension-filled as it is, takes a back seat to an exploration of a man's change of identity
The doc admirably makes the case that the food prepared by top chefs on the island of Taiwan is the world's most succulent.
movie_title: Das Rohe und das Gekochte (The Raw and the Cooked) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Though snail-paced, this post-World War II look at a teen girl's effort to change her attitude toward Jews and National Socialism is worthwhile largely because of the beautifully acted role of the title figure.
Though the film has contemporary resonance, the structure is rambling and the audience wonders: who did what?

Overlong and bleak while featuring superb ensemble acting, this Romanian Oscar entry employs careful attention to detail to depict life in a remote chapel as perhaps a stand-in for the greater society.
A serious, hard-hitting doc that eviscerates the know-nothings who claim that global warming, if it exists at all, has little to do with the activities of big corporations.
Painterly with a bold soundtrack but ultimately pointless look at men at sea who bring in our Friday dinners.
Don't look for logic here, but who says that romantic love is logical?
A compelling story of family dysfunction on a French vineyard is buoyed by an Oscar-worthy performance from Niels Arestrup.
Not much knew if you've been following the news on a regular basis, but the doc punctuates the serious problem, finding hunger in the midst of plenty.
Even if you're a young guy with no interest in the prescription drug scene, you'll be attentive to the melodramatic aspects of this psychological thriller.
A thriller based in Syria with grainy photography, absurd coincidences, one that is stiffly acted with stilted dialogue.
Italy's Oscar entry for best foreign pic of 2012 is a bold choice, one featuring hardened criminals who deliver a shattering performance of Shakespeare's Julius Caesar.
The conversation between the elderly professor and the call girl is amusing and mysterious in equal parts.
Neatly combines political conflict with marketing satire to form a vivid look at the 1988 plebiscite that overthrew Chile's dictator Augusto Pinochet
A tender but happily unsentimental tale of a closeted gay doctor in Israel who finds at least a measure of happiness with a young soldier.
Retired members of Israel's Shin Bet security people are surprisingly honest about their country's policies toward Palestinians.
A loopy satire of "Alien" and similar horror tales with more laughs than scares and an incredible array of visual effects.
Despite its adaptation from an airport bookstore novel, the movie rivets, the 130 minutes flying by like the inevitable crime-story police chopper.
Tells us more about 'The Shining" than we ever thought possible, though not a single interpretation voiced in this doc could be accurate.
Where is Judd Apatow when we need him?

Broadway longevity notwithstanding, 'Les Mis√©rables' is not a great musical. But the current screen version could have been so much better if real singers were used instead of box office draws like Jackman and Crowe.
The definitive answer to the existential question, 'What the frack?'
A subtle work acted with restraint illustrating a woman's conflict between duty and desire.
Behind some assassinations is the obsession of a woman.
Severely tests the marriage vow "...in sickness and in health..."
Harrowing story of a family's separation following the tsunami of 2004.
Underneath waves of jocularity and vulgarity lies this sentimental undertow: we may not be as witty as Apatow's characters but their lives are not too dissimilar from our own.
If moviegoers under the age of thirty skip this feature, they're missing a comedy that will show them what their lives will be like decades later--if they're lucky.
A coming-of-age movie filled with songs and probably based on director David Chase's own teen years in a rock band.
Animatronic photography is so incredible that five-year-olds might be scared and adults will be riveted.
The doc about the transfer of ownership of a top French restaurant is workmanlike.
The emotional range is too limited
Sprawling, unfocused account of family dysfunction.
Watch this one, Mayor Bloomberg. If you succeed in prohibiting 32-ounce soda in New York, our city could turn into the Franklin County of 1931.
Happily Spider-Man 4 deals largely with human relationships and romance rather than non-stop action.
A furiously-paced comedy that goes where none has gone before.
A costume drama well acted but marred by hazy film quality.
Beautifully photographed, handsomely performed World War I romance.
Adultery is easy; comedy is hard. But what lifts this film well above mediocrity is the presence of Woody Allen himself after a six years' absence from acting.
A barely accessible look at the permeability of identity recommended as a reflection of the director's vivid imagination.
This powerful doc is surpisingly only the first to attack the victimization of tens of thousands of women in the armed forces by their own fellow soldiers.
To paraphase a critic, "At a time that so-called major directors are producing anemic works of little interest, 'Killer Joe' is a source of optimism."
The performance of Mark Duplass, who could be called Mr. Mumblecore for specializing in low-budget indies, is the reason to see this.
A character-driven look at a diverse bunch of individuals whose past is catching up with them. Talky, like so many French films, but featuring lots of twists.
Sharply shot, edited and costumed doc about a fake Indian guru who teaches his disciples more than he could have imagined.
Striking CGI, inept narrative.
A romcom in the Woody Allen style whose laughs are dependent (too much so) on the lovable personality of its title character.
Though the film is drenched with atmosphere, a vampiric Robert Pattinson has neither the gravitas nor the chemistry needed to bring De Maupassant's novel to cinematic life.
Has a terrific cast and laughs throughout.
Jane Fonda as a hippie grandmother is the reason to see this comedy.
Often hypnotic, this small, well-acted piece focuses on a middle-aged man intent on fulfilling his departed mother's final wish.
Though humorless and anchored by a two-register performance from Charlize Theron, the picture must be seen for its enchanting recreation of an alternative, medieval universe.
A humorously ironic look at what the filmmakers believe to be incompetence and corruption at the United Nations.
Even a film with great eye-candy like this one fails to satisfy as it lacks a solid screenplay.
A stirring, even epic dramatization of an actual war in Mexico pitting a brutally anticlerical government against forces fighting for religious freedom.
Missiles have the only sensible dialogue in this otherwise technically awesome picture.
A documentary-style drama portraying the training of a seeing-eye dog is sentimental and convincingly acted by both human beings and Labs
movie_title: Quill: The Life of a Guide Dog (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Stirring doc about one of Israel's great heroes, known particularly for rescuing hostages at Entebbe airport in Uganda.
movie_title: Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A semi-autobiographical story of a man's over-reaching, which leads him to consider violent options in dealing with himself and his family.
Well-meaning but innocuous.
A sensational thriller that is both a satiric examination of the principal character's feeling of inadequacy and a scary look at a man's frantic attempts to escape a killer.
Too schmaltzy, but so what? See it for Morgan Freeman's performance.
Effectively combines romance with historical fiction about the question of what to do with Emperor Hirohito after the Japanese surrender in 1945.
Ultra-violent but also satirical, with dark humor, luscious photography, and convincing performances.
Supernatural doings in a hopelessly chaotic movie.
A Holocaust 101 film that focuses on the roundup of French Jews in 1942 from a child's point of view.
A suspense-filled dark comedy about a doctor obsessed with an 18-year-old patient.
Dull car chases, embarrassing dialogue, humorless comedy.
Eye candy that will take you to 25 countries without the hassle of airport delays.
Get ready to cringe or crawl under your seat (that's a compliment)
Though outrageously biased (refusing to show how Hamas provoked a war with Israel), the graphic shots make for an indelible entry into the archive of anti-war films.
An exquisite collection of archival films graphically portraying the passions pf demonstrators that resulted in the release of drugs to counteract AIDS.
Oozing with undeserved sentimentality.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: You want scary? Stick to the ghost ride in Coney Island.
If you've ever gone away with friends, living in close quarters day and night, you'll identify with this ensemble-dominated film
A delightful, subtle Israeli coming-of-age comedy-drama.
Stellar photography and effects cannot quite make up for the staleness of the series and the flatness of the principal character when compared to Matt Damon.
Makes you wonder whether Britain and China were wrong to allow Hong Kong to remain a free-market capitalist province--though the movie does not compare in quality to "Wall Street."
The therapy in Maine with recommended intimacy exercises for a couple married 31 years will be found hysterically funny by some, embarrassing by others, and for me, well-acted and simply amusing.
Opening as a light, bright tale of romance, the musical-drama becomes increasingly complex and portentous.
Family mayhem becomes more embarrassing than funny, but there are enough chuckles and a few belly laughs to make this well-acted piece worth seeing.
A sexual roundalay showing that what goes around, comes around. Indeed.
An adorable fantasy about a man who learns that being able to manipulate his girlfriend into doing everything he wants is not to be taken as desirable.
A look at the worldwide sushi industry with emphasis on how overfishing of Bluefish tuna could wipe out the species in five years.
Bruce Wayne/Batman opens his scene brooding like Hamlet but rises when the movie becomes full of sound and fury signifying...well, something, more or less.
A trans-genre Iranian love story that is exquisitely cast, edited and photographed
A stunning look at what happens to a rich person who gets greedy.
More a reasonably involving family drama than the broad cinematic portrayal for which the director is better known.
Richard Wagner would be overjoyed to see a production of his Ring cycle staged in a manner that was impossible in the 19th Century.
An epic drama whose significance is symbolized by citations from Shakespeare and the operatic world.
Sisters engage in tedious, seemingly unending melodramatics.
Gives the impression that a city council campaign in Seattle is followed by only a bunch of youths whooping it up.
Grainy photography captures a story lacking suspense.
A low-budget sci-fi that lucidly explores the emotions of a man and a woman who grow from suffering loss to expressing forgiveness.
Does not create the same impact as the best-selling book, but seeing it is almost a patriotic duty.
Yes, Aniston delivers a serious performance but it is over the top and turns the movie into a soap.
Brings to life a largely forgotten heroic action by the King of Norway to refuse capitulation to the Nazis.
Yet another warning that guns kill, graphically and patiently shown here in a drama of a man who is accidentally shot though the shooter feels guilty enough to confess.
Brea offers a surprisingly energetic look at chronic fatigue syndrome, which has derailed her life.
The Chilean director projects the angst of adolescence in a casually-paced drama about violence and family dysfunction.

As director, Angelina Jolie brings to life all the horrors of revolution and war, told through the point of view of a five-year-old Cambodian who later wrote a memoir of the tragic events she witnessed during the Pol Pot regime.
Men and women find a way to communicate without speaking in this prison movie which is probably an original for the genre.
An innovative look at a Chinese immigrant's involvement with a voluntarily homeless person in Buenos Aires.
A dialogue-heavy detective drama with little emotional appeal.

The hospital that watches over 100 births a day is not the kind of place Americans would like to use when their water breaks, but the Manila institution does have a spirit of camaraderie and the doc is an original.

Can two women, opposites in personality, find meaning in each other's company? Just watch two of France's great actresses performing as two distinct personalities, exchange vibrations and meet almost in the middle.
Combines moral allegory with detective noir in its probing look at the quest of a young doctor to relieve her feelings of guilt.
A single dad has his hands full in a narrative film that will give viewers insight into the nature of autism.
The titillating theme is that Van Gogh's gunshot wound was not self-inflicted, but what makes this movie sui generis is that it is the first fully painted feature film.
A coming of age tale of a 13-year-old African American living in rural Arkansas that captures the boy's heartaches and urges, though English subtitles would make the picture more accessible.
Raises the controversial and Orwellian view that killing animals conserves their species. Top safari photography.
Advises that prisons are not rehabilitation centers. Who knew?
Devastating sci-fi about what happens to a country when families are restricted to one baby each.
Capitalizes on the chemistry between and eleven-year-old African-American girl and two Asian-American retailers.
Little more than a video game with dialogue that seems improvised--and badly.

An exciting entry into dance cinema with feminist resonance as a woman studying ballet quits her job at the Bolshoi to take her chances with modern dance and ultimately rises to the status of choreographer.
A middle-aged woman who had married young and yearns to re-live her high-school days gets more than she bargained for at the hands of a horny 18-year-old and an old-fashioned ice cream man.
Brotherly love following a botched bank robbery recalls John Steinbeck's "Of Mice and Men."
A justified reaction to police brutality makes one wonder how so many juries can find the authorities not guilty, even refusing to indict police.
Seemingly mindless domestic terrorism and a surprising response from the authorities.
One character notes that his country is not Switzerland. This noirish detective story with allegorical touches is like a morality play about systemic corruption.
Small talk is happily abandoned as two people--a mature Korean-American man a 20-year-old woman--discuss the meaning of life, each offering advice to the other.
Cheerfully brainless with as many digressions and distractions in its 129 minutes as Donald Trump can offer in about that time.
You don't have to be a dance aficionado to appreciate the story of this dancer who spent a decade in Israel for the Batsheva group.
Prosaic tale of a woman Marine with PTSD.
A close look at an odd couple: a Chinese-American journalist who tracks a homeless man who is not what she originally thought he was.
Will Smith comes close to saving this one.
A gripping tale of corruption in the Chinese-American community.
A pure delight follows a gay couple in Baja California who lobby for the right to marry there.
Who better to discuss the horrors of the Nazi concentration camps than those who had been imprisoned there?
Frances McDormand is in Fargo-like high form.

Not your typical high school movie. This one portrays Dahmer (performed by an amazingly copied look by the title character) as a kid who might have been stopped from murder if adults paid attention to his adolescent fantasies.
A reasonably absorbing look at the dismay of a rape victim when she finds herself smothered with "understanding."
A fair and balanced poll taken on election day sporting a record number of directors (18).
The photography, saturated color something like the earlier Technicolor pictures, gives further authenticity to the project.

Though Wright directs only a few scenes of pure melodrama, his interpretation of Churchill's character visualized through all the man's hesitations and doubts, may be the most authentic yet portrayed on film.
Feminism triumphs as Swiss women push for the right to vote.
A strong performance by Melissa Leo as a Mother Superior anchors this absorbing film.
Though there are comic moments, this is a serious drama exploring themes of family, marriage, crime and especially the frustrations of aging.
The charismatic subject of this doc may be blind, but he's obviously playing with a full deck.
Few pictures dealing with the Holocaust examine as carefully and respectfully as this one the theft of Jewish homes by the local people and their resistance to returning the property to survivors.
J.K. Simmons plays a poignant role of a grieving father who, together with his son, seek love after a family death.
The year's most exciting entry to date flawlessly mixes Hitchcockian thrills with the supernatural as a doctor, a man who "plays God," is harmed by a diabolical teen.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Reportedly no more than two percent of Hasidim leave the fold. This picture is an apt dissection of a few who wanted out and left.
Anthony Bourdain stars as narrator of this wake-up call: some forty percent of food that Americans buy is sent to landfills, contributing to a toxic environment.
movie_title: Wasted! The Story of Food Waste (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Too much of this dialogue-driven theatrical piece is whispered.
Finland's entry to the Oscar competition for best foreign language film gives the audience a detailed, emotional look at one of the gay community's heroes.
See this and you'll believe the study that finds new college grads have no better reasoning powers than when they were freshmen.
A look at the degradation of both men and women under the folly of Nazism, a Holocaust film with more than a few traces of creative originality.
The one's an original: well cast, good songs, and a look at what it's like to be conjoined twins who are exploited by those in authority.
This family friendly movie shows with beautiful Colorado backgrounds how a 57-varieties mutt saves a man's life and possibly his marriage.
An adaptation of a Stephen King novel that subtly and without irony shows the imbalance of a marriage when the woman is handcuffed to a bed.
First-class editing helps to make sense of a jumble of plots, including Tom Cruise's performance as a gun running CIA agent, a TWA pilot, and a drug smuggler.
Grueling French tale about what happens when two people no longer in love refuse to move out.
Happily, the government hires women for its space program. Otherwise, how would we get this remarkable film?
Mixing lyrical interludes with a concrete story line, this Mexican film is an enchanting look at the deterioration of both a language and a deep friendship.

Fans of Edward Albee's "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf" will eat "The Dinner" up.
From Guy de Maupassant's first novel, "A Woman's Life" exquisitely confirms the tagline "Life is not as good or bad as you think."
Not as tightly structured as the director's superior "Fill the Void," but provides insight into the culture of Israel's ultra-orthodox.
Vivid dramatization of the reforms made by Dr. Nise to save psychiatric patients in Rio from the brutality of lobotomies.

movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Forgettable.
A respectable enough treatment of a romantic triangle set against the horrors of Turkey's genocide of Armenians in 1915.
Rampart absurdism makes this film an acquired taste, especially for those not lucky enough to be French.
As soulful as your computer monitor's announcing "Blue screen of death."
Far from the methane-filled air of Beijing lies a paradise for pandas, snow leopards, and antelopes, beautifully photographed.
A National Geographic-style feature with a Masterpiece Theater aura.
These youths party, they argue, they philosophize, and most of all they smoke--in a nonfiction film that's shot in a New Wave style but goes nowhere.
A street magician with a magnetic personality baffles spectators in a reasonably entertaining naturalistic drama.
A subtle tragi-comic view of a man who appears to offer the world to people he befriends but does not really offer them anything at all.

movie_review_blurb: Some originality at work in contrasting the vision of a man who had lost his sight and regained it.

For a vampire movie, this one is too refined.

Goes well behind the antiseptic hospital scenes to delve into the lives of the people in the drama.

Unless you're shot by James Bond or a host of other blockbuster heroes and collapse instantly, death takes time. Believe it by watching a king pass on. Louis XIV has all the time in the world to enlighten you.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A serious exploration of the mind of a young woman who seeks revenge for being bullied or ignored by parents, peers, and the whole Czech society.
An irritating title character appears in an unfunny comedy with saccharine sentiment.

Intriguing in that it lays out the case that we can now make jokes about the Holocaust and lets the viewers decide for themselves whether they've made the point.
A serio-comic drama that portrays a dying man's wishes and actions and proving that for consolation, there is nothing that can take the place of good friends.
A bloody send-up of office politics.
Don't make your family pay for a death notice in the New York Times. "Obit" will inspire you to do something great, which means the paper of record will grant you a free placement.
A hard-hitting antidote to viewing society through rose-tinted glasses.

Despite their aloofness, or maybe even because of it, the hundreds of cats roaming the streets of Istanbul have the luck of being fed and petted by the good-natured citizenry.

Vengeance is served by a woman wronged.
A refreshingly original take on a young man who is kidnapped by a couple wanting a child and who later lets loose with his creative urge.

Probably the best film in cinema history whose plot is driven by a young man's tinnitus. I dare any other studio to have a better soundtrack this year.

An honest, feel-good look at the ambition of three former dropouts determined to earn a full-scale high school diploma.
Though a drama about a serious subject, this is the year's funniest movie to date.
Watching this Altman-esque film with its vivid characters embraced by exquisite photography could teach you more about the culture of Moscow than you could learn from being there for a week.
Nuns acting like drunken sailors: funny in Boccacio's time, maybe, but forced humor today.
A flamboyant coming-of-age cum monster movie with some of the flashiest visual effects you may see this year.

Demetri Martin proves to be a Renaissance man in directing, writing, editing, illustrating and as principal performer in the delightfully comic look at how father and son cope with grief.

Arf dog movie, half military drama, and both worth you time.
In his campiest role, Brad Pitt gets right into the character of the man playing General Stanley McChrystal.
A thoughtful look at the need for forgiveness.

Michael Keaton's character shows that you can make a fortune dishing out junk food to customers who know no better.
Wild festivities.
Quite a ponderous treatment of Chile's greatest poet.

Young Palestinians and Israelis meet in Germany to discuss their differences. Background filming is ample. The dialogue between the two groups is same ol' with the result that they may leave the conferences with even more hatred.
Argues that some Romani music has African foundations.

Next time you feel sorry for yourself for a broken air conditioner, think of how much better off you are than the tens of millions of people chased from their homes, escaping from war, famine and poverty. Devastating.
Two men played by Steve Carell and Bryan Cranston deliver soul-searching performance, telling off the Marines who insist on buying a dead soldier where they want to bury him.
The scenes in the museum are overextended to the point of viewer frustration.
Expect to be outraged when you see an African-American man incarcerated for 21 years for a crime he did not commit.
Who knew Wyoming was a such a dangerous state?
Despite its length of two hours and ten minutes, the story rolls by so fast, the narration by the principal character so literate, the facts so detailed, that you won't have time to check your watch.
Now if the Iranians followed only their rich tradition of storytelling and poetry!
Too much sterile rumination.
Wolverine is as great a showman here as he was as MC of the 2009 Oscar ceremony.
The highlight is Christopher Plummer's performance, one so villainous, yet believable, that you'll want to throw rotten tomatoes at the screen.

Does not work as either satire or entertainment.
Writers like Hemingway often have exciting lives. This biopic enthusiastically tells of another exciting young journalist who risked his life to write about Somalia.
The film evokes sadness as we watch Hedy Lamarr, once considered the world's most beautiful woman, give up a chance to make big money on her major invention and withdraw from public life as she aged.

As a physically handicapped folk artist, Sally Hawkins's performance is even better than it was as a cleaner in "The Shape of Water."
A generally insipid road movie with the usual Alzheimer cliches.
The year's best sports movie is not about football or baseball, soccer or boxing; it's about figure skating and has enough chills to call it a thriller.
"The Room," a movie that had audiences laughing AT the director is transformed into a laugh-out-loud film that has us laughing WITH the director.
Transgender rights get a punchy treatment in this effective drama.
It's fun, especially nowadays, to cheer when a President who thinks himself above the law is brought down by a free press.
For all we know, an authentic look at high-school life focusing on the myriad talents of Saoirse Ronan (her first name rhymes with "inertia").
Gorgeous Tuscan scenery forms the backdrop for a 17-year-old's coming of sexual age. He has the kind of father we all probably wanted.
Full of life, this swinging doc shows the fervor attending a throwback to the 1920s, dancers who enthusiastically go back in time to give new spirit to the Lindy Hop.
This expertly crafted narrative shows Arab-Israelis as you've never seen them before, breaking all the major taboos of the group's long-standing culture.
Slavery corrupts owners as well as their enslaved as this starkly beautiful, dreamlike fable assures us.

A sweet comedy, an antidote to the over-the-top, vulgar and politically reactionary 'Borat.'

More evidence that you don't need animation to supply cartoon characters.
The doc is likable not so much because of the wisdom of the 40 subjects but from the vivid archival films and the energetic creativity of these participants.
A richly textured and wholly satisfying mix of French and Korean cultures.
Heavenly music and compelling commentary from one of the world's foremost violinists who is also a mensch.
Snappy dialogue of the kind favored by David Mamet is its strong product.

A must-see for sexually active women who want to become virgins once again.
You can't be blamed if you want to leave this party early.
Perhaps Ozon's most playful movie.

Black lives know how to spoof the inclination of police to target them-- with some hilarious results.
After seeing this delightful doc, surely nobody can doubt that dogs are man's best friend.
Makes fun of parents' murdering their children. A flop that lacks even entertainment value.
Gets us right into the life-style of Romanis, particularly those who are coming of age.

A refreshing, intimate look at the kind of people that Trump voters dislike.
Not only an awards-worthy performance from the wonderful Diane Kruger but a movie that should be Oscar-nominated.
