Loses momentum but fans of electronic music won't mind at all.
One of Mark Ruffalo's most engaging performances.
Their protests probably won't accomplish much but they're having fun and so will the movie audience.
It's difficult to become involved with losers who are either uninteresting or downright irritating.
The heartbreaks resulting from World War One take life from this adapted memoir of a woman who loved and lost.
A disaster.
Will appeal to lovers of "Frances Ha."
Structurally too loose but the music in the soundtrack is awards-worthy.
Absurdism to the point of incoherence.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Sloppy editing can cause major confusion.
Fabrice Luchini is the principal reason to see this delightful serio-comic reimagining of Flaubert's classic "Madame Bovary."
Incredible special effects and production design, insipid, flat story.
Regina Cas√©'s standout role as a housekeeper more attached to her employers' family than to her own anchors this Brazilian look at family dysfunction.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mountain climbing the evokes moments of exhilaration.
Depressed woman finds love with her tour guide in Costa Rica. Who wouldn't?
A terminally charming movie about ambition, family values, and raw fish.
Spectacular visuals cannot make up for formulaic plotting, banal dialogue, and by-the-numbers acting.
Like our own overlong Presidential campaigns, this film could use a more aggressive editor to weed out repetitious campaign speeches.
An ultra-violent narrative film, probably authentic look at the role of child soldiers in African civil wars.
"Jane Eyre" this is not. Instead, "Crimson Peak" seems to use admittedly smashing costumes to cover up a lack of compelling narrative.

With Steven Spielberg's direction, the Coen Brothers' writing, the performances of Tom Hanks and Mark Ryland--two of their generations' leading actors-- and a phenomenal production design, how could this not be one of the best movies of 2015?
History's most famous experiment in social psychological gets dramatic treatment here.
What's it like for a kidnapped mother and daughter to live together in one room for seven years and never leaving it? "Room" has two excellent performances to tell us.
While both political parties seek to win over Hispanics, a few U.S. residents want to kill them. This narrative film tells the latter story graphically.
Jon Stewart could not have done a better job skewering the far-right wing of our country.
Though Michael Fassbender contributes an Oscar-worthy performance, the fragmentary nature of this biopic is distracting.

A crowd-pleasing film that resembles "Slumdog Millionaire" albeit without that film's complexities, "Trash" contrasts Rio's gorgeous beaches with its notorious favelas and has strong performances from three youths.
Another reliable performance by Cynthia Nixon.
Who's better at this kind of horror movie than Eli Roth?
Slasher parody runs out of steam in just a half hour.

Though not a film with a tight narrative structure, this look at the Holocaust from the point of view of one of its prisoners is likely to be the most visceral experience you will have in the movies this year.
Filmmaker Jafar Panahi deserves credit for continuing to satirize the Iranian government's restrictions on freedom, but as drama, "Taxi" is simply not that interesting.
By the numbers it may well be, yet this movie, about the fight for gender equality, will succeed in rousing its audience.
Essentially a two-hander with solid performances and minimalist dialogue.

This documentary may be devoid of animations, f/x, stirring music, and vulgar jokes, but it can be of considerable interest to those of us who have been hospital patients or their visiting family and friends.
Gorgeous, National-Geographic style photography cannot compensate for a clunky narrative and vague characterizations, which militate against emotional impact.
Director M√©lanie Laurent conducts this 91-minute drama at a leisurely pace, getting terrific performances from the two leads.
Teachers come across as the usual movie stereotypes while the zombie kids simply run around chasing humans as a generic pack.
A road-and-buddy movie Middle Eastern style wherein director Fatih Rahim falls short of reaching epic status.
A no-holds-barred expos√© holding that a hefty percentage of the German population in the thirties and forties worked for the perverse interests of the Nazi Party.
A film that includes cross-dressing and is loaded with charm, wit, humor and drama.
This notable feat of cinematography shows much the world Islam's holy city of Mecca but is more of the inner journey of a gay Muslim than it is a travelogue.
A stunning documentary that hones in on one individual's attempt to take over a town and populate it with racist extremists.
Imagine a film critic who smugly condemns movies that he calls "cliche-ridden" only to find that his own life is following the trajectories of the movies! Clever.
Entertainment this is not. Strictly for a cult audience.
A mature, adult, thoughtful and credible sci fi entertainment.

In his seventh collaboration with Catherine Deneuve, director Andr√© Techin√© focuses with amusing results on both romance and politics--on a young woman who loves too much, and a casino owner's enemies determined to wrest control from her of a casino.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If this were a parody of romance, the film might be considered valid; but somehow the cast and crew appear to treat the venture as realistic.
For lovers of mature musicals, fans of Anna Kendrick, and devotees of cleverly plotted love stories.

A most effective antiwar movie though an oversimplification that seems to say that if you get two enemies to sit down with each other over soup, shashlik and a hard-boiled egg, a peace treaty will soon emerge.
A colorful, fast-moving genre-blender, comedy and psychological thriller, workable thanks to Ryan Reynolds' nice-guy demeanor.

How do ballet dancers get to Lincoln Center? Practice, practice, practice, and this inside look at two months of rehearsals for a newly minted ballet is an eye-opener. Big plus for a doc: there are no talking heads.
What does a gal have to do to obtain a divorce (a gett) from an Orthodox Jewish man? Quite a lot as this fascinating courtroom drama indicates.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating tale of a secular Jew's attempt to get a Haredi wife to free herself from the confines of Orthodoxy.
Too little action, too much rambling conversation.
Typical January release: predictable, trashy, over-the-top, but not without entertainment value.
The refreshing camaraderie on display from this group of energetic teen girls will sadly evolve into a life of menial jobs and perhaps incarceration.
Al Pacino modifies his usual hammy style in this satire on May-December romances and commentary on the transitory nature of celebrity.
If you want to know what it takes to be a world-class photographer, you don't want to miss this movie.
Few movies show the rage between the British Unionists and the Irish Republican army as effectively as "'71."
If you wonder why writers go to the country for peace and quiet and get nothing done, this lively movie will provide one answer.
A fast-moving story of friendship and of hockey anchored by an interview with the charismatic ex-player Slava Fetisov.
A great example of a story that indicates the relationships between actors and the people they portray.
Its many thrills are punctuated by a great score and two terrific performances.
If the movie deserves criticism at all, it should not be because it's juvenile (it is, and proudly so), but only because the largely improvised jokes are hit and miss.
A sympathetic look at mental decline in a middle aged woman.
Easily the funniest satire of the year.
A subtle look at corruption in Russia.
Too much naturalism, not enough style.
If you can disregard its politics, you will see perhaps the most exciting adventure thriller of the year.
Involving look at both a unique style of painting and the evolution of a fraud.
In this overlong musical, Red Ridinghood is so obnoxious that she drags down the movie.
Generally entertaining but Mark Wahlberg is no Kevin Spacey.
Watch sparks fly when sonny and mommy are in a room.
All style and little plot, but your senior prom date should be as beautiful at 17 as Salma Hayek is at 48.
Has elements of "The Players," "Mulholland Drive," and "Myra Breckenridge."
A startling doc about college rape that is torn from today's headlines.
A stirring performance against type by Jean Dujardin as a nails-tough magistrate helps make this a riveting police drama.
Carey Mulligan is a delight to watch in her authentic recreation of a feminist looking for a man who is able to "tame" her.
Kristen Wiig may well be the top communicator of dry humor in the movies today.
War is hell and love is difficult in this epic-style, old-fashioned Hollywood movie.
Warm, believable performances by this ensemble.
Slow-moving undramatic doc with desultory narration but deserves viewing because of its subject matter.
Of special interest to people already committed to animal welfare.
With its sumptuous photography, razor-sharp editing, and a delightfully comic narration by Tin Fey, "Monkey Kingdom" shows us like no other film in recent memory how closely animals act like people.
A potentially sophisticated conclusion is wrecked by a conventional ending.
Clever exploration of a cat-and-mouse theme featuring the exploitation of a journalist by a convicted murderer.
A naturalistic story that turns into an attention-grabbing psychological thriller as friend blames friend for the death of a fellow vacationer.
Not even Emma Thompson can breathe life into this middlebrow look at Victorian rigidities.

Of special interest to a limited audience, this backstage look at fashion design at the house of Christian Dior will tell you what you always wanted to know about the most elite segment of the rag trade.
Effectively warns us: Do not commit adultery
movie_title: A Wolf at the Door (O Lobo atr√°s da Porta) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A classy comedy about the generation gap and the ubiquity of manipulation.
A survivalist drama made all the more scary since it is based on a true story and since the bears are real, not animatronic.
As in "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf," both the younger couple and their older mentors are changed from a relationship.

If the matador got gored, this would be a marginally better movie, but Sean Penn's g.f. is too young for him, Javier Bardem is an embarrassment as a drunk, and the frantic fight editing is the usual standard stuff.
Will attract Pacino's regular fans and the soap opera crowd as well.
Seymour Bernstein's playing is technically marvelous, and in addition, his warm personality transfers to the music.
A wonderful movie that scores high as political allegory, Grand Guignol, and coming-of-age drama.
A hallucinatory trip down the rabbit hole that summons memories of Gus Van Sant's "Gerry."
Jaw-dropping.
Reasonably taut drama based on the actual kidnapping of the beer mogul. Too bad everyone speaks English instead of Dutch.
A romance that leaves all principals heartbroken, as we in the audience will be as well.
If you can believe that two guys would each carry $1.2 million cash to the racetrack, you can accept anything this picture throws at you.
A poor man's "Sweet Hereafter" features Amy Morton's strong performance but is poorly photographed with occasionally incomprehensible dialogue.
Diane Keaton and Morgan Freeman make a cute couple in this theatrical comedy about a pair of house-hunters.
An inert vanity project.
A Fellini-esque treat for eye and ear.
An energetic band of sisters become sexually repressed by their grandmother and uncle with tragic results, as the film shifts easily from comedy to serious, satirical drama.
The filmmakers are so frustrated by the amount of food that North Americans waste that they determine to eat only thrown-out grub for six months.
movie_title: Just Eat It: A Food Waste Story (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An alternately sad and jocular look at a father's attempt to bring his daughter closer through a series of practical jokes.
A rousing look at conditions of ante bellum slavery that led to the most famous bloody resistance movement.
Daniel Radcliffe as never before seen infiltrates the weirdos in the American Nazi movement.
As though two polar opposite directors were fighting over methods, the movie's first half is painfully slow, giving way to a rapid-fire video-game-like shooting gallery in the second.
A decent enough story bogged down by an unappealing principal actor.
movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Arguably among the most authentic movie treatments of the adolescent's world.
A bizarre, cross-genre production that is a war movie, a suspense film, and a metaphysical creation. The viewer will be left with the impression that it's better not to join the military.
movie_title: Neither Heaven nor Earth (Ni le ciel ni la terre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A suspenseful thriller which should have the audience gasping every time that the drug lords are about to expose the customs agent who has infiltrated their network.
Overly simplistic sci-fi evoking better works like "Gattaca," "1984," and "Code 46."
High-end Woody Allen, exquisitely evoking the 1930's in Hollywood America.l
Clever but manipulative.
Tom Ford's returns as director after a seven-year break with a psychological thriller elegantly blended with romance.
Sad and soapy.
A tense spy tale in the John Le Carre tradition.
A look at two creative adolescents with a sweet nature.
An intelligent, family-friendly documentary that takes an extensive look (without hidden cameras) at farms that produce our meat, eggs, and milk.
Didactic rather than rousing.
A somber look at heroism and villainy within a Polish convent in 1945.
A cute, off-beat tale, separate narratives of people whose lives are bound together by a Dachshund.
A talking heads documentary featuring intellectuals, both Christians and Jews, now living in Germany. Didactic more than it is compelling.
What's refreshing is that this doc about Argentina's rich folklore avoids clich√© by covering every dance and song BUT the tango.
A theatrical piece with cinematic flair.
A charmless, witless attempt to satirize the Nazi era, asking What if Hitler succeeded as a painter?
The doc makes a strong case albeit without many animations and other effects that intelligent animals like chimps should be classified as legal persons.
An offbeat look at a pre-teen who wonders to what extent she should give up her individuality to fit in. The title could have a double meaning: epileptic-type spasms, or fitting in.
Political discussions take a back seat, way way back, to a combination of clownish villains in Halloween-style costumes and seen-it-done-that shooting gallery action.
A revenge tale, but one done in the sophisticated European style rather than the simpler Hollywood treatment.
Though the unconventional biopic does not often spring to life, Natalie Portman's awards-worthy performance must be seen.
If you've ever been lost, and who hasn't? This movie is for you, featuring a five-year-old boy from India who winds up in Australia.
The adorable dog at the wedding did not say anything. That made him the most interesting guest at the reception.
A compelling, minimalist look, dark in spirit as well as in lighting, seen from the point of view of the apprentice to a hangman in Singapore.
This poor man's Lawrence of Arabia is a swashbuckling World War One tale involving a Muslim man's love for a Christian woman amid a background of people determined to kill each other.
An exquisitely crafted tale about the friendship, even love, of two people on opposite sides of the fence, a German man and a French woman, just after World War One.
Kitsch romance amid Uncle Joe Stalin's pogroms.
An entertaining,satiric documentary aiming at the irrationality of the Church of Scientology. Acted-out replicas of actual events take the place of the usual talking heads.
This first-class psychological thriller blending a comedy of manners into full-scale mayhem will appeal to both intellectuals and rank-and-file moviegoers.
A neo-nazi converts to Orthodox Judaism. Intruiging.

With stunning use of archival film coupled with interviews and events from recent developments, this documentary will be an eye-opener for both those who think they know all about the Israeli settlements and those who seek an inside look at the politics.
Soft-core porn: hard bodies and limp dialogue.
This psychological thriller/horror movie needs to be cut by one third to speed up the action. Slow going until the final twenty minutes.
James Baldwin died in 1987 but his views on race relations seem so 21st Century that you might swear he is alive today.
Could be a hit with the high-school crowd.
An authentic look at street life in Harlem with the suggestion that the high incidence of crime results from the lack of male role models.
A look in some depth at the damage both done and potential of far-right militias with a principal focus on Timothy McVeigh's bombing of a federal building in Oklahoma City.

Do dogs love us only because we feed them? This delightful tale answers the question and should be of special interest to all children and as well to adults who have been owned by these wonderful, four-legged friends.
For a film about financial elitists, this has a reasonably exciting populist vision.
Justifiably chosen as an Oscar semi-finalist, this stunning film demonstrates with appropriate nuance the mixed feelings of a Danish sergeant toward his German captives.
Not only a gorgeously photographed epic of historical fiction but of current relevance given the persecution of "the other" by terrorists and benighted residents of civilized countries.
Pedro Almodovar once again demonstrates his talent for highlighting the complexity and beauty of women.
A scathing indictment of how the government of an industrialized country treats working taxpayers who become disabled and must jump through hoops for a minimal income on the dole.

Watching the shootouts, the audience might say, "Looks like another video-game scene" and yet we're told that the action throughout the movie is an authentic working of actual events during Boston Marathon.
Valuable nutrition information that they do not teach in med school, but course level 101 if you've not kept up with recent controversies.
Feminism in Mongolia is given its due in a soaring film that should have the attention of awards groups for its spellbinding cinematography.
Casey Affleck finds his best role as a depressed handyman whose life acquires meaning when he take charge of a teen nephew.
Warren Beatty's having as much fun in this movie as he had in "Shampoo" 41 years ago.
Cerebral sci-fi with a Spielbergian sense of wonder.
A saccharine, but quite watchable British romantic drama with a goofy principal character
Director Rebecca Miller explores her inner Woody Allen to goofy effects.
Destined to be looked over by awards groups for costumes, make-up, production design and effects, but all of this barely makes up for its lack of narrative coherence.
As with many feel-good comedy-dramas, Welcome to Happiness has quite a few dark moments, but then, Oliver Thompson shows himself to be the guy to watch for future fantasies of the Wes Anderson type.
This satiric treatment of technology compares to the novel "The Circle," which is the gold standard for such.
This Monty Python-esque treatment of the 2008 economic crash makes your losses almost enjoyable.
Not unlike an older woman's wet dream.

Featuring Mozart's gorgeous music, "Marguerite" is a comedy cum pathos based on the ambitions of a rich woman who thinks she has an operatic voice and an audience of sycophants who refuse to tell her the truth.
Too sane and predictable to be effective satire, nor should you expect the surrealism of a "Dr. Strangelove" or the humor of a "Mash."
A taut film, photographed in real time, that supplements vivid action sequences with a moral debate.
The real horror, beyond that of the crimes themselves, is that an elderly. respectable-looking, middle-class man manipulates his family into participation in murderous kidnappings.
A slow, poetic, zen-like look at the bonding of three solitary, flawed individuals.
There have been other docs about the modern history of Zionism, but this one is about as good as you'll get.
Forget the flowers and chocolate this Valentine's Day. Instead, invite your sweetheart to this lushly photographed , epic love story from India. There's no dancing but the couple really kiss!
A dissenting view of growing capitalism in China told dramatically through heartbreaking human relationships.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An absorbing story centering on the commander of a small Danish unit in Afghanistan whose action evokes the conflict between the demands of the law and the moral judgment of a man under extreme stress.
A day in the life of a movie "fixer" forms the unifying bond in a delightful film that satirizes and pays homage as well to 1950s pictures.
A shattering, though darkly humorous, tale of abusive priests and one nun whose crimes have been covered up while the accused have been sent to live together in a remote Chilean town.
An indictment of prescription drug overuse is limited by the relative absence of graphics and humor.
A provocative look at a long-term marriage that had me thinking, Hey, what did the guy do that was so bad?
Think what you will about the veracity of this usual one-sided doc, but can you at least admit that Michael Moore is the most entertaining maker of documentary films?
Surrounded by a lively ensemble of party people, Tina Fey and Amy Poehler are in their metier making vulgar comedy for just short of two hours.
Saccharine romance aside, this biopic is a hard-hitting broadside against the brutality of football.
Who needs clever dialogue when you can watch Leo DiCaprio groaning and grunting for a considerable part of the movie?
A sometimes surreal, always hard-hitting ensemble piece about the corruption that led to the financial crisis of 2007-2010.
Watching these two brats who have nothing interesting, witty or humorous to say, soon becomes tedious.
Two awards-worthy performances make this a stirring fictionalized account of a passionate romance not cut short by a man's transgender surgery.
An exquisite, classically crafted story that conflates the romance of the journey to the New World with the tenderness of a woman's first love.
Three immature men seek the Holy Grail, which to them is attending an awesome party, but the film itself may achieve its own Holy Grail: to win this year's Golden Raspberry (Razzie) award.
A thoroughly entertaining doc about sometimes inscrutable cartoonists but focused on those sophisticated readers who indulge in subscriptions to the New Yorker magazine.
Though repetitious, this muckraking documentary exposes the dangers of chemicals that corporations put into some of their products.
Humdrum disaster movie.
Watching Kristen Stewart texting a mystery man is about as interesting as observing the messenging by four teen girls at a restaurant table ignoring one another while buried in smartphones.
This doc is like a loving commentary on the value of immigrants, who have made Los Angeles not just the city of movies but of food as well.
Visual effects are front-and-center in this thought-provoking sci-fi pic.
If only our Economics classes were as exciting as this darkly humorous look at high finance!
Not among the best of Jane Austen's novels is given a decent adaptation.
A muddle of mayhem.
One of Ralph Fiennes's best performances and the gorgeous scenery on a Sicilian island doesn't hurt.
The picture's surrealism requires an attentive and particular audience which will find rewards therein.
Intriguing tale about an individual whose mounting debt leads to unfortunate circumstances
Jesuthasen's ferocious performance as a former child soldier in Sri Lanka now living in a tough French suburb anchors this Cannes Festival prize-winning film.
A quirky film that asks, Are these parents monstrous or simply creative?
A feel good biopic providing insight into the mind of a mathematical genius and his friendship with a mentor from a different culture.
An exuberant look at a son's need for his father's acceptance.
The documentary offers a nuanced view of the Kitty Genovese murder.
Ravishing scenery forms the background for a stellar performance from Agyness Deyn in a romance ultimately thwarted by the beginning of World War I.
A subdued domestic drama, without much punch.
An imaginative narrative comedy based on the unrecorded meeting between President Nixon and Elvis Presley.
A neo-Nazi converts to Orthodox Judaism in this absorbing and credible film. Is world peace around the corner?
A slasher pic that fails on most levels: production values, music, dialogue, performance, clarity of purpose
As naturalistic as a movie can get, this features an astonishing, if restrained, performance by Vincent Lindon.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du march√©) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Stunning ensemble dancing actually shows a correlation between hip-hop and classical ballet.
Jake Gyllenhaal's steroid-like performance makes you almost believe that he would destroy his own house to recover feeling.
This doc will be looked upon as either an indictment of government censorship or a lame attempt by discredited scientists to revive a theory against vaccinations.
The titled lovers succeed in making North Korea and its previous despot so bizarre that you'd think the whole movie is science fiction.
A stunning breakthrough performance from Rod Paradot as a feral adolescent anchors this Cannes Festival opener.
Serves as a travelogue and a gender-bender, highlighting a man who is a macho rodeo ranch hand by day and who operates a sewing machine at night.
Is the ensemble responsible for this sit-com conspiring to suffocate us in the audience, just as they portray a suffocating Greek family?
A comedy that's neither clever enough nor sufficiently over the top.
With surreal touches, "Francofonia" persuades the viewer that museums are not simply storage rooms for old paintings, but symbols of a culture's identity.
A film about the failure to communicate does communicate well thanks to a stellar ensemble cast performing as a family trying to cope with tragedy.
Dramatically shows how your experiences as a youth influences you for the rest of your days.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Frantic action compensates for a lack of character development.
A delightful romance between an upper-middle-class WASP and a working-class Latino.
Kevin James is about as funny as Bud Abbott, which is not a compliment.
A light, bright comedy of manners, Gallic style.
Though graced with a performance by the fascinating Asia Argento, this noir film is difficult to follow.
The film is meant to be a heart-stopper but does not succeed as the director had hoped.
Comes across as an intellectual study of the horror genre, featuring some superb acting and a cuttingly intelligent script.
We knew that high-school senior year would be fun--but this much fun?
The story of a young man with a flexible sexual imagination is marred by an annoying central character and by the superficiality of the songs.
Despite the failure to credibly connect modern corporate practices with Nazism, this exquisitely acted film is watchable throughout its 144 minutes.
Foul.
Flamboyantly puts across the idea, Be careful what you wish for. Ambition, power and wealth are not what they are cracked up to be.
A chick-flick with lesbian undertones featuring three meshed stories of little dramatic interest.
If you do not believe that divorce can be among the most stressful events of a person's life, you will after this intense film.
A doctor who does not care about money or status? Must be one-of-a-kind, and this documentary does him justice.
A sentimental British sex comedy anchored by a delightful performance from Marianne Faithfull.
The trouble with this movie about amateur film-makers is that the entire film comes across as amateurish.
Ultimately a crashing bore in all its dismally grainy (what passes for) photography.
An energetic film with pleasures both intellectual (the initial segment) and visceral (the concluding portion).
The picture takes its time in developing momentum; once attained, it becomes a watchable, optimistic cri de coeur.
The movie is performed so well that you come away thinking that high school years are both the worst time of one's life and the most joyful.
Miracle to behold, director Brooks gives us in the audience a romantic comedy that is head and shoulders above the routine pap that the major studios throw at us annually.
Scary enough to give free "midnight movie" nightmares to some of the young 'uns in the audience. What could be better than that?
Has enough originality to distinguish it from other caper movies.
A warm, humorous story showing that there is no obstacle that can prevent a small child from finding his loving mom.
Uninspired sitcom about a man visiting home to a family that disrespected him as a youth.
Seek cinematic gold elsewhere.
Even an experienced viewer of supernatural pics will get an occasional jolt: I got mine from watching Jessica Alba's character about to push her right eye out of its socket.
The director makes a convincing case against the extremism of property rights when those rights trample on the needs of the public.
Since this is a Cinderella story, Amy Adams is perfectly cast as is Frances McDormand as a dowdy governess morphed into a princess.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though the humiliating treatment of prisoners at Abu Ghraib has been shown before, Errol Morris creatively uses re-enactments and animation to hammer home his points.
A Holocaust movie with quite an original twist--about a tollbooth collector who imagines himself to be a survivor of Nazi horrors.
Girls just wanna have fun but the trio of adolescents in 'Water Lilies' have anxieties that act against that natural desire.
As a spoof of a spoof the picture becomes repetitive and tiresome in spots but remains entertaining enough to deserve a visit.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gags fall flat as many times as they sparkle, but the comic take on surrogate motherhood features some Saturday Night Live veterans that are having a good time and are eager to please their audience.
A Middle East primer for Americans who've been living in caves like Osama, delightfully juvenile entertainment for everyone else.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Helen Hunt effectively combines comedy with melodrama in a story of a woman whose biological clock is ticking.
Director Lelouche has a ball playing games with the audience, tossing out red herrings, genre-bending with murder and romance.
Exquisitely acted story of a intersex teenage 15-year-old girl who will not commit herself to surgery to correct the duality of genitalia.
[A] harsh, frightening and stunning dissection of Church history.
An engaging, sexy film the punctuates one of the many unusual ways that women today can become pregnant.
Makes political points via a fascinating tale of an unlikely friendship between people of vastly different cultures.

The adept performances and sharp direction of this thriller allow the viewer to see the writer-director's point: that life in communist East Germany may have been preferable for some to the more prosperous existence in the West.
A step down from "Superbad" and "Knocked Up," but still funny enough to be near-vintage Judd Apatow.
A dated, unfunny sex comedy.
Street Kings has a brisk pace and performers who look as though they wish they had brighter things to say.
A genuinely funny, intelligent, entertaining tale of a man on his way to becoming likeable, bland and borderline-insipid.
Doesn't match the brilliance of Mike Judge's 'Office Space' but has enough amusing moments to merit your look.
A terrific documentary that hones in on the Israeli government's decision to forcibly evacuate 8,000 of its own citizens from Gaza.
A heartwarming doc about the decades-long struggle to free Jews from Soviet oppression.
Chiwetel Ejiofor's powerful performance as a jiu-jitsu instructor steeped in the virtues of honor anchors David Mamet's intriguing film
A credible evocation of screwball comedies.
For special tastes: for others, the film is static, punctuating the harried life of a mother who frankly does not have much reason to be frazzled.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Director Peirce appears to view both rah-rah patriotism and a keen sense of cynicism at the same time.
What distinguishes Flawless from other movies of the kind, unfortunately, is its absence of humor.
The deck may not be the only cardboard character, but this re-telling of an actual event efficiently combines intellect with melodrama.
A tearjerker made credible by the director's patient pacing.
The banal story serves as an excuse for some stylish, moody photography.
The entire film is just too low-key and bland to stir enthusiasm.
There's vulgar funny ('Superbad,' 'Knocked Up') and vulgar unfunny. 'Drillbit' is the latter.
Good chemistry between Gleeson and Farrell, lots of wisecracks, laughs and blood.
The satire is anything but nuanced in this zany comedy targeted to the 17-35 set, and that's just how its audience likes it.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With Rambo, you know what you get and you get it. The big question is: what countries will he save when he's 70? 80?
If you're a news junkie, you'll find nothing new: if not, this nicely-edited and eminently watchable doc will open your eyes.

An embarrassing chapter in America's history of race relations becomes the scene of wonderful uplift in Denzel Washington's moving and true story of how a small African-American college debating team took on Harvard's in 1935.
Muslims and Jews can indeed get along, and famously. Just have them teach in the same elementary school as this cute little, low-budget indie brings out.
The rave meter does not point north, as this pic has just enough fantasy not to outlast its welcome.
The old and the young really do have something to say to each other as pictures like this one (along with 'The Water Horse') tell us with so enjoyably.
Humorously shows how a parent in second childhood helps his immature son grow up quickly.
A smidgen of originality lies in its being a noir film with Korean characters: others nothing new, but still a watchable gangster pic.
The title character is the kind of hip, articulate, whip-smart teen girl you'd both love to have as a kid and find awfully challenging as well.
A better adaptation would have left the monsters off screen throughout and stressed the psychology of the locked-in residents who erupted in virtual civil war against one another.
A simple picture, well-cast, that takes a middle view on the virtues of arranged marriage versus the benefits of freely choosing your own partner.
Amy Adams looks and sounds as if she indeed emerges from a fairy-tale land.
Coppola's latest won't break Godfather box office records but give the man credit for taking risks making an intellectual, philosophical fantasy with Faustian-Wildean-Kafkaesque undertones.
Freddie Highmore, still the cutest kid in the movies, is an endangered species, about to turn 16 in February and allegedly not intending to continue as an adult actor.
If everything that documentarian Alex Gibney reports about torture is true, then America has not only become corrupted morally, it is using a technique that does not even work.
A Scottish actor struggles with an Irish thesp to maintain a lower-middle-class London accent but Woody Allen succeeds in maintaining tension in mining melodrama territory.
Stellar acting by two youths makes believable the theme that you can go home again both geographically and morally.

Director Robert Zemeckis does the impossible: makes an enjoyable experience out of the most tedious poem in the English language. If Mel Gibson directed, he would have made it in eighth-century English with no subtitles.
Though an original idea, it's not so far out: Haynes does a never-dull job of showing the many personae of a man who has no central core and who is not at all defensive about that.
The Zen priest who dominates the film as its talking head is laid-back to the point of being soporific and engages in speech mannerisms that could make even an adolescent hit the ceiling.
Beautifully photographed adaptation of a major British novel that illustrates the value of counting to 10--make that l,000--before doing anything rash.
A seamless mixture of riotous humor and socio-political commentary.
Even if this 1982 movie were made in 2007, it would be hailed for its special effects and production design.
If the picture is talky and the dialogue sometimes stilted, that's a small price to pay for a drama that attacks the American public's diminishing sense of commitment.
The title character is far from lovable, but John Cusack's charm is irresistible
If only every bee were named 'Chris Rock' the movie would have the stinging humor it sorely lacks.
While it has the appearance of a made-for-TV weepie, it's well-acted, technically proficient, a solid story with genuine, credible emotions.
Virtually no-one is likable, which is fine for those who like movies with snarky dialogue and cynical characters like this one.

Director Jessica Yu backgrounds her four talking heads with an ancient Greek puppet show to demonstrate skillfully that we've been going through the same neurotic cycles of behavior for the last 2600 years.
The first half, the sci-fi part, is fine; the second, the same ol' undead horror segment, is tune-out time.
Alex Etel's adorable acting makes this one of the most charming of the year's kids' movies.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Reilly is well-cast in this hit-and-miss spoof of both rock singers and American social history from 1950 on.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though similar to Schindler's List, this riveting Holocaust drama, also based on a true story, features actors who throw themselves wholly into the violence of a brutal concentration camp as they practice a trade that could keep them alive.
Nicely mixed lighter-than-air comedy with poignant moments amid Brazil's political authoritarian governments in the 1970s.

movie_review_blurb: A genre-bender that has elements of Douglas Sirk, Oscar Wilde, Alfred Hitchcock and Joseph Kesselring.
Insipid characters speak dialog so banal it makes Andy Tennant's 'Fool's Gold' sound Shakespearean.
Director and principal performer Nadine Labaki juggles a series of romances but the love that shines through the most is her passion for her city of Beirut.
The 3-D cameras are as enthusiastic as the U2 rock musicians.
Scenes move ahead in a plodding manner. Since the film's hero is supposed to be a man without charisma, he cannot rivet an audience.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A tongue-in-cheek amusing movie--but being literally tongue-in-cheek can sometimes be dangerous.

I sure left the theatre convinced: It's natural all the way for me. Jeeves, draw me a bath.
An implausible story centering on three characters whose differences in social class and temperament make the proceedings less than involving.

Remarkably imaginative: Director Morgen merges archival film with animation to bring to life the excitement of youthful demonstrations against the Vietnam War during the '68 Democratic National Convention.
Sonny Blake turns out a literally electric performance on his electric guitar.
Bland. Difficult to believe it was written by the scripter who penned The Devil Wears Prada.
A banal weepie.
A love letter to the singer.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A stunning performance by newcomer Jonas Ball in the role of Mark David Chapman, the killer of John Lennon.

movie_title: Imaginary Witness: Hollywood and the Holocaust (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A critique of capitalism that's light as a corn flake.
Anna Faris is alternately hilarious and annoying in this stoner comedy.

Despite a fairly original premise, this never rises above the level of a TV sitcom.
Worth seeing if only for the locations (Paris, London, Washington, Mt. Rushmore) even if it goes downhill after the brief opening scenes from 1865.
While too closed-in and stagy to be effectively cinematic, 'Sweeney' is still an effectively blood-curdling revenge thriller and perhaps a satiric commentary on capitalism's cannibalistic thrust.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You can choose to risk a heart attack watching these skiers take off on 55-degree mountain passes or breaking your neck trying imitating them yourself. Thrilling sport. Great photography.
Some humor, specifically the title character's womanizing, is dated and no longer shocking. Otherwise, the movie is political satire light and amusing enough.
Baffling ending notwithstanding, a stunning performance by Daniel Day-Lewis in a film that won five awards (of a total of fifteen) from New York Film Critics Online.

Skolnik, who directs and scripted Without the King, brings vivid, highly critical life to this hapless country.
Visually sumptuous but marred by a fragmented tale.
For those who can appreciate bold cinematography at the expense of a coherent story.
A pleasant way for old-timers to learn what a 'mix' and a 'playlist' are.
Anne Hathaway does not cut it in films that are not fables.
Brims with vivid imagination: an animated documentary that serves to exorcise the director's demons.
this adeptly-made movie will wake us up to how cynical we really are (in comparison to Mike Leigh's the title character).
A soulful tale of anomie in America.
A sentimental comedy adept at evoking both smiles and tears.
Sam Rockwell's charm gives this pic its deserved kudos.
Bring back Hopalong Cassidy and Randolph Scott and you've got the making of a respectable horse opera.
Transports us headlong into the bleak lives of some residents in the Missippi Delta.

Much originality and crackling dialogue in this police drama about a cop who opposes interracial marriage.

Wisely uses the docudrama approach rather than talking heads to dramatize the 1999 protests against the World Trade Organization.
Its originality is stunted by a hodgepodge of pretentious scenes.
Despite its predictable story, "Greetings" does not wear out its welcome thanks to the casting of the radiant beauty, Kim Shaw.
Rich in atmosphere and family values.

Surrealism is on vivid display in this series of three shorts that form an ode to the city of Tokyo.
Scarier than a movie with Freddy Krueger.
A slow albeit riveting look at a 30-year-old married man who has regressed to childhood for a while.
Well made and acted but lacking edge-of-your-seat suspense.

A cynically effective look at the suffocating lives endured by some of the rich and famous.

Overly sentimental but a must-see for Mickey Rourke's astonishing performance as a pro wrestler seeking a comeback.

An insightful, well-acted serio-comic look into the mind of a creepy 18-year-old Scot.

A seamless mixture of horror and low comedy.

A girl and a horse: that's love. What more can we want?
A pleasant enough diversion if you can get past the 'Borat'-like embarrassment of slapstick moments.
Take a note: This is Judi Dench in the performance ofher career as a needy teacher who exploits and almostdestroys a younger woman.
The audience may want to know nothing more than, Will Lohan look as good as Fonda a half-century from now?
Messy, unfocussed sci-fi.
A stunning, even electrifying view of communism in EastGermany as a soulless regime.
Not your typically silly Bollywood offering, this relatively short Indian saga is pretty to look at, demonstrating with gentle humor how a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do.
Quiz show aptly shows that wisdom is preferably to knowledge.
To see what real romantic comedy can be, compare this to superior Grantsmanship like 'Four Weddings' and 'Notting Hill.'
A young Bosnian woman learns that her dad is not the heroshe thought he was in a dramatic postwar family drama in Sarajevo, Bosnia.
What distinguished this horror pic is its emphasis on the personal--on love of family rather than the fight against the beast
There are a few moments of striking visuals along with Mauro Fiore's generic Vegas cinematography, but nothing that can't be done about as well in a video game.
A comedy with considerable depth about people who suffer despite their living amid the splendor of one of the most fashionable areas of the world.
Lacks focus with its plethora of family entanglements.
Can actually make one sympathize with those who oppose Madonna's adoption of a poor African lad.
The material is awfully familiar, and first-time director James Ponsoldt paces the entire 90 minutes so slowly that you might think he's talking about chess rather than baseball.
A superb contribution from an A-class film-maker.
The acting is as impeccable as Remi Adefarasin's lensing is gorgeous.
Resembles a vanity project that looks as though every frame was submitted by producer-director Simon to Mr. Walsch for his approval.
ill be cheered by a relatively small, but educated and curious contingent of ticket buyers.
The film is happily as fast paced as the sport of basketball itself: there are no bearded, stuttering academics discussing any aspect of the story.
What's the point of knowing what there is to know about a fellow when we get only sound bites of what he has done with his enormous talent?
Revenge begets revenge is the moral here in a beautifully photographed genre Western showing off New Mexico's climatically varied scenery.
Though a cookie-cutter crime tale, this one stands outfor some fierce ensemble performances.

To the documentarians' credit, you will leave the film pondering the one big question: did Nader do the right thing to stick by his principles, or should he have held his nose and supported the lesser of the two evils?
Amid all the cynicism, the barbs directed by the world at America, how refreshing it is to see our country standing up for our true ideals!
The cotton-candy colors threaten a diabetic attack but thereare good action sequences and good-natured performances.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Had traces of human feeling, but [it's] mostly didactic.
Ben Stiller may just be his generation's Woody Allen.
Handsome man deals with neurotic wife by having unlikelyaffair with mother of criminal lad.
Give Stallone credit for originality--turning a sports pic into a trip down memory lane.
Effectively shows how good intentions without forcefulbackup can lead to impotence and disaster within aforeign culture.
A marginally involving dramatization of how peopledeal with AIDS in 3 separate cultures
Confusing until you see all the loosely connected shortstories in the series.
This might charitably be called a victory of style over substance, except that there's little of either on display.
A downer all the way, Even Money makes for dandy entertainment -- the perfect antidote to anything inspired by Hallmark that's sent our way this year.
The movie is about as interesting as a duck would be as a pet.
Daniel Auteuil is reliable as usual.

A stagy piece that allows the audience to wonder how much is going on in the central character's drug-induced hallucinations and how much is real--No matter, though, since nothing is particularly dramatic or original.
A majestic biopic that digs more deeply into the character of Jesse James than has ever been done before. Will disappoint fans of shoot-em-ups, though.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cronenberg comes through once again with a stylized, original look at relationships within a mafia family and between its driver and a nurturing woman.
A generic war movie with the usual rapid editing, jerky camera movements, and confusion exacerbated by the film's cut from 150 minutes to its present 110.
A vivid, visual experience that will easily convince skeptics that slavery is alive and well.
Michael Douglas plays the year's most lovable cuckoo.
This one's all about performance: Ms. Foster's as a gun-toting angel of vengeance overcomes flaws in plot.
A stylish matching of verbal wit made less interesting as language sits out the physical action.
Remarkable performance by Valerie Harper in this one-woman show from the Broadway play focusing on Israel's former Prime Minister, Golda Meir's, critical decisions during the 1973 mid-East war.
A beautifully photographed look at a dozen people in Portland, Oregon who find that love is far from an unmixed blessing.
If Emile Hirsch is short on charisma, he nonetheless whets our wanderlust--though if you're thinking of trekking to Alaska, go with a commercial tour group.
If you've ever been baffled by the culture of another country, you'll have particular empathy for the principal performer of this delightful comedy.
Charles Bronson is alive and well in the form of Kevin Bacon.
Terrific, envelope-pushing gun fighting that both parodies and pays homage to Sergio Leone and John Woo.
Focuses quite well on a relatively unexplored niche: the theft and also the destruction of valuable works of art by the Nazi regime during World War 2.
A poignant--if hardly credible--gay West Side Story, Middle-Eastern style.
Listening to these two irritating people in a movie that's not scary is exasperating.
Predictable sitcom but delightfully feel-goodish.

First-time writer-director-producer-actor is a fellow to watch. This debut film, which won 40 awards at festivals, is a trenchant, albeit tearjerking, look at a 17-year-old on the road to self-destruction.
Actors of this caliber deserve more than a conventional actioner with banal dialogue, virtually no humor, and a rushed, highly improbable conclusion.
An acquired taste with its quirky camaraderie and forced humor.
Claire Danes may play a fallen star, but the real star in this pic is the visuals.
The only problem with this insanely funny movie is that it's going to incite envy from anyone in the audience who thought high school was for studying.
Using real film (unusual in a doc), director Kohn avoids the trap of endless talking heads giving dramatic form to the crime and corruption endemic in Brazil.
A sober, melancholy recreation of a journey that Primo Levi took mostly through Eastern Europe, after his liberation from Auschwitz.
A splendid reinvention of the 1957 movie alternating vivid gunfights against a gorgeous background with brain-games of the most manipulative sort.
Bombastic music and lavish costumes cannot disguise the film's coming across as a ho-hum high-school lesson in historical fiction.

Can be looked upon as an anti-Communist tract and an implied statement about abortion, but far more important, this is an incisive film about two vulnerable people at the mercy of a cynical abortionist and an underground economy.
Not as bloody as 'Hotel 2,' but because we know that the horrific events really happened, 'The Girl Next Door' is at least as scary.
movie_title: Jack Ketchum's The Girl Next Door (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Audience members who found previous Coen brothers' works too precious can rejoice in this, their best film--close to an American masterwork.
Even second-rate David Lynch and third-rate Federico Fellini is worth our attention.
Has the claustrophobic feel of 'Das Boot' but is static: no pitched battles, little humor, no women, overlong.
It's to Jonathan Demme's credit that he creates an angelic view of Jimmy Carter despite the former president's reprehensible view that Israel practices a South-African style of segregation.
Straddles the line between European-style art-house fare and pure American soap opera.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The dramatization of child sexual slavery comes across more involved in education than entertainment, its tone less melodramatic than what we found in 'Trade.'
The remarkable story of a man almost totally incapacitated who creates a best-seller by blinking his left eye is about the creation of art as much as it is the tale of human tragedy.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A gem of an animated movie which subtly and comically jabs the Iranian regime while unfolding the spiritual journey of a woman from 1978 to the 1990's.

An often gripping doc using never-before seen archival films about the self-assured, unrepentant Jacques Verges, who defended some of the most loathsome terrorists and political criminals in modern history.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Convoluted plotting inhibits clarity, with editing that resembles cut-and-paste jobs.
Well acted but merely a competent police drama with family overtones.
Performers are convincing enough to keep audience involvement in a tale of revenge: victims become victimizers.

Ridley Scott deftly contrasts the character of his two principals, demonstrating that the drug underworld is organized like legit corporations, obsessed with competition, fair prices, and quality products.
The idea is original, the story is sweet, but repetition sets in making it difficult to bond with Ryan Gosling's bland, introverted character for long.
Though the story comes across as merely heightened TV fare, stellar acting by Joaquin Phoenix and Mark Ruffalo keep us in suspense.
Seamlessly mixes campy comedy with sentimental romance: an epic film based on a Nobel Prize winner's novel.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly unfunny dumbing-down of the 1972 version, leaving out the subtleties of social class and ethnic friction of Neil Simon's script.
Let sleeping dogs lie.

In a role that reminds one of Peter O'Toole's in 'Venus,' Frank Langella is receiving buzz as a potential Oscar nominee in the role of an aging novelist emotionally charged by a visit from a graduate student 45 years his junior.
As is usually the case in movieland, a powerful US agency is the villain. The use of torture is frowned upon, and a complex plot provides reasonable tension.
Unsympathetic characters, a lead performer that does not register, and a script that comes across like improvisations do not bode well for Jake Paltrow's debut feature.
An absorbing doc that punctuates the idea that abortion, legal or banned, is not a black-and-white issue but is in a political gray zone.
A moderately amusing shaggy dog story that evokes director Wes Anderson's love for human beings with quirky personality traits.

An elegant film featuring a stunning debut feature performance by Tang Wei that serves to enlighten us about a little-known resistance movement by Chinese against the Japanese occupiers during World War 2.
Melodramatic in tone, complex in thought, this 'Clayton' is a thinking person's John Grisham.
It's no 'Exodus' but is a reasonably involving primer on the birth of Israel in 1948, specifically on the fighting for control of Jerusalem.
Cliches aside, this is a ghost story with class, with riveting acting by the central character, one which metaphorically deals with the pain of great loss.
When the depressed Paul jumps from the bridge into the Seine, I was hoping he'd not swim ashore. There is not a character here that one could care about.
Adolescent angst in a movie that's about as quirky and unpredictable as a film-maker can get.
A predictable story with too many minutes spent with a gang just hanging out but featuring two extraordinary performances.
Marine Captain Brian Steidle, who went to Darfur to monitor a peace agreement but instead became a witness to genocide, should be considered by Time for Man of the Year.
Touches a universal chord: that of families who never discuss sex and love with their teens. But this Korean drama has a glacial pace.

Yes, it's sentimental and you have to suspend disbelief (why would the crowd mock Evan as a loon, since after all, 100 pairs of animals are watching him build the ark?), but it's an entertaining enough pic albeit one not crammed with laughs.
Don't expect the fireworks of 'Amadeus,' but the film will show you why Mozart, who died at 35, is considered by some to be the greatest musical genius of all time.
Yet another doc that socks it to the current administration's foreign policy--this one most effectively.

Its major drawback is its failure to allow even a single dissenting argument, but Moore proves again to be the most entertaining and opinionated documentarian in America and greatest opponent of greed.
If there's a better model of passive-aggressive than this Joshua kid in a recent movie, I'd like to know of one.
Two scripters let their imaginations soar to show us how Moliere would act if he became a character of one of his plays and met people from his other productions--and it works!
'Vitus' could show a blank screen, play the soundtrack, and still be more intelligent than half the movies at the multiplex.
While avoiding the most important travesty--the use of animals for food--the documentary does efficiently illustrate the arguments for an against the use of animals for research and fur.
The film is little more than a foundation for Parker Posey's usual fine performance, as the story lacks wit and narrative drive.
It's an OK revenge pic but Dan Klores's revenge movie, 'Crazy Love,' costs 1/400th of the price to make, and is a superior film.
It's about time that New Zealanders got their share of some ribbing.
Artfully done, allowing us to be so caught up in the build-up that we can wait patiently for the gore.
Only the Taliban could dislike the joyful music on display herein.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: When the tabloids reported that a woman married the man who blinded her, disbelief: this vivid documentary helps one understand--a little.
A threadbare Holocaust drama that could be of some educational value in middle schools.
While the documentary is well intended, that of parents' willingness to forgive three punks for murdering their son, the direction is uncreative and dull.
The problem with this movie is that Billy Connolly never gets to open his mouth wide.
The alter-ego gimmick works nicely thanks to terrific Costner-Hurt teamwork in this gripping, complex thriller.
Effectively shows how an executioner kills over six hundred people before coming to end of his rope.
For what this one picture cost, you could make 8,000 pictures like Mike Akel's 'Chalk' or 2,000 like Adrienne Shelley's 'Waitress,' and each would be better than 'Pirates.'
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: People in Australia a thousand years ago laughed more spontaneous than we do today and they had no clothes, cell phones, TVs, condos: 'Ten Canoes' is so well told you can believe it.
Too many shifts back and forth in time but Marion Cotillard gives a towering performance as Edith Piaf.
Serious documentary about one of the most important researchers of the 20th Century responsible for bringing major Nazi criminals to justice.
movie_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life And Legacy Of Simon Wiesenthal (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Luke Wilson makes the case that he can act just as cool and laid-back as his brother Owen.
If you're a high school teacher, you might find the funniest scenes painful to watch.
The one-liners are sustained throughout the entire 132 minutes.
An engrossing look at a rarity, the only four Americans who ever defected to North Korea, with a warm look at the first, James Joseph Dresnok.
We wait a long time for the political points to become resonant as the movie slogs through aimless, dull, family chit-chat.
Korea's obsession with plastic surgery is satirized with humor and warmth by Kim Ki-duk using an attractive ensemble of young Korean actors.

Anyone who has ever had to undergo a grueling interview for a job or for college admission will relate to this witty albeit stagey story of seven candidates competing together in one room for one job.
Who better to write about murder in the Hamptons than a pair of brothers who live there all year 'round?
A snappy, funny animated picture with much of the dialogue suited for adults in the audience. Too bad the satire is so mild.
While the story is a composite of cliches, the salsa is grand--as is the chemistry between J Lo and her real-life husband, Marc Anthony.
Incredible, almost nonstop action, replaces the demands of plot, character, explanations, and downtime. That's not necessarily a bad thing, depending on your expectations.
While no one will mistake director Anthony Giacchino for Michael Moore, the documentarian unfolds the drama of the arrest and eventual not guilty verdict of 28 Vietnam War protesters in 1971.
Buscemi again proves himself one of our great character actors in the role of a paparazzo who feels regularly betrayed--by his parents, by the celebrities, and by a homeless kid he helps.

Despite some unintentional laughs and the difficulties some actors have with the English language, 'Goya's Ghosts' is worth seeing for the color, the costumes, and an education into the perils of irrationality.
Sporting chefs who look more appetizing than those found in 'Ratatouille,' 'No Reservations' is harmless, predictable, and an entertaining time at the movies.
[A] generally torpid movie.
Among the merits of this small film (that could easily find a niche on cable TV) is a view of the Hamptons in the dead of winter when only salt-of-the-earth people and murderers remain.
A slight Korean comedy with stereotyped characters.
A pair with good chemistry who are ultimately mismatched--he a neurotic New Yorker and she a man-hungry Parisian--make for solid comedy entertainment.
This one could have been really funny except for one thing: it's not 1950.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though the pic is as talky as anything by Erich Rohmer,the dialogue is riveting.
Who knew that Baltimore was this bouncy?
Awesome CGI, cliched human drama.
This one would have fared better as a boxing movie rather than a sentimental pic about an ethically-challenged man's relationship with his 6-year-old son.
Though critics often denigrate today's overuse of special effects, more of those are needed as the human interactions are a crashing bore.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: We're in Woody Allen/Christopher Guest territory here with a bright, fast-paced sitcom without the required happy ending.
Exhilarating! I say, 'Bring back the sixties' (minus the Vietnam War).
Going to this movie is at least a more enjoyable way to spend the Fourth of July weekend than participating in the Coney Island hot-dog eating contest.
Director Cherie Nowlan knows how to blend comedy and drama seamlessly in a delightfully offbeat Australian tale of a domineering mother and her 20-year-old, tethered son.

Ratatouille is the best of the eight movies that Pixar has offered to date. It has color, glorious music, a fast pace, a clever and witty script, a credible villain or two, and the one thing everyone in the audience loves: lots of delicious food.
Some originality still exists in action-adventure movies: how about the way an airborne chopper is brought down by colliding with a car? Great stunts, some wit and humor.
Solid performances allow 'Evening' to transcend the label 'chick-flick' as a woman on her deathbed ponders whether one mistake she made fifty years ago destroyed her life's happiness.

When Mike Enslin (John Cusack) says he does not believe in ghosts, we in the audience cannot be blamed for not wishing him well, but he does turn in a stellar performance in what largely a stagey, one-man show.

Winterbottom avoids a documentary format but the movie is so lacking in suspense that it becomes the equivalent of a talking heads doc. Without Jolie's fine performance, the project could be easily dismissed.
Christian Bale's performance quality is inversely proportional to his weight. He's anorectic here.
A barebones-budgeted sci-fi B picture that's more of an intellectual exercise than a source of chills and thrills.
Seriously underwritten, depending too much on Liv Tyler's abiity to pout, to shriek, to cry and to cry again.
The film will be nominated for gorgeous cinematography, the landscape forming the backdrop of a story that is more conventional than the sort director Luhrmann is accustomed to.
A superb French gangster pic that will remind moviegoers of 'Bonnie and Clyde.'
An impressively photographed doc using one family to stand in for what each year forms the greatest migration in history.
Photographer Zhao Xiaoding captures the sunsets, his sun turning the sandy hills of the desert a mysterious red.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Anemic sci-fi that works neither as romance nor adventure.
Finally: a dog story for an adult audience!
A richly colored, swiftly-paced Chinese murder-comedy.
A formulaic rom-com with some sharp dialogue and a solid performance from a six-year-old.
A conventional biopic lacking in passion but of great importance toward understanding the Norwegian resistance to Nazi occupation.
Jet-paced, funny, classy, graced with moments of pure magic.
Awesome photography but possessing more schmaltz than herring shoppers will find at Zabar's on a Sunday shopping spree.
Though marred by repetition, this film is a four-year labor of love graphically dramatizing the kidnapping industry in Sao Paulo.
A revealing look at the French Resistance but one that is more intellectual than action-packed.
An inert thriller that should have remained on the novelist's page.
See this soulful doc about a piano competition and you'll never again think that "amateur" means "less than professional."
An intelligent, tension-filled policer from downunder.
Though not a doc that speeds up the pulse of the audience as it should, 'Neshoba' graphically shows us the atmosphere that led to the killing in 1964 of three civil rights workers in Mississippi.
A decent screwball comedy, nothing more.
A documentary record of the ghastly conditions existing in the Nazi-occupied Warsaw Ghetto in 1942.
Only marginally suited for a Hallmark Hall of Fame TV episode.
Don't expect a sophisticated Broadway musical, but this Australian piece gains its melodious charm by its simplicity.
A blood-curdling pulse-pounder about France's best-known bank robber.
Salt will raise your blood pressure.
Yet another plea for a plant-based diet, but the doc has entertaining animation and easy-to-follow interviews.
This schmaltz is better suited for TV's Hallmark Hall of Fame.
Resembles a photographed play about a family decomposing within amid the lush sub-tropical vista outside.
Awesome design, effects and stunts, but where's the story?
An imaginative package but one filled with too much cartoonish fighting.
Hugely violent, well-acted, with a plot that lacks complexity of, for example, Eli Roth's 'Hostel 2.'
Everyone wants to touch the belly of a pregnant woman.
Hanky-panky in the English countryside is delightful, traveling well across the Atlantic.
Too unassuming for its own good.
British royal history doesn't get more interesting than this.
The widely anticipated, blazing climax of the Swedish trilogy.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A thriller that relies as much on domestic friction as on international politics.
One of the most underproduced musicals of this or any other year.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Western lives!...in Southeast Australia.
Effectively horrific tale of the illegal organ transplants business.
The violence that preceded Algeria's independence from France is brought explosively to life in this dramatized tale of brotherly love.
Javier Bardem displays the intensity needed to put over a seedy character determined to redeem himself when afflicted with a terminal disease.
Dirty Harry has mellowed with age, not entirely a bad thing.
Finally! Proof that art is garbage, garbage is art.
Standard-issue rom-com
Paul Giamatti's momumental performance anchors this epic tale.
A rousing, feelgood tale of a woman's success in getting equal pay with men in her factory.
A pedestrian doc about one form of political corruption in the U.S.
Diane Lane shines as the horse's owner.
An intimate, dark comedy about manipulating your family from beyond the grave.
A shy British Indian woman of the Muslim faith meets an outgoing Jordanian Christian woman, neither of whom can think straight in this entertainment from the mysterious East.
Bottom line? Kind of a funny story.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A sharply written tale expressing the irony that a man with five hundred million subscribers has nary a friend in the world.
A story that should have been told with more fire.
Not the people the Brazilian Tourist Board wants us to see, and perhaps not the people you would not want to spend time with either.
94 minutes (in real time) of slow suffocation makes for an unusual entertainment.
A documentary about a Facebook scam that sometimes looks so polished that it looks like a fictional setup.
Don't expect Michael Moore's style of humor and irony in this largely pedagogic doc about autism.
movie_title: A Mother's Courage: Talking Back To Autism (S√≥lskinsdrengurinn) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Kristin Scott Thomas is the only reason to spend time with this soap.
An intimate, witty comedy-drama that evokes thoughts of 'The Seven Year Itch'
A dull, scattershot doc about people who do NOT vote against their interests, since they consider social issues of greater import than economic ones.
A terrifying tale of a woman who refuses to escape from a country torn apart by civil war.
This low-budget indie can be appreciated by folks who want to see the real New York.
Nicely captures the milieu of, and the action in, the Go-Kart racing world.
What's really lost in Rio is the participants' sense of humor.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne r√©pond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Films with a distinct view are welcome but not when they are as minimalist, grainy, bereft of soundtrack music and lacking in entertainment value as this one.
With considerable attention to detail, the doc takes the view that Congress is influenced by cash. What a surprise!
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Reasonably amusing doc about a salesman whose strong (read: weak) language gains fame.
Solid ensemble work with an especially good Catherine Keener.
The theme of a man's aging and loneliness is intriguing but that violence is cartoonish.
Scarier than anything Freddy Krueger could have dreamed up.
Effectively warns against leaving Eden for Sodom, a vivid portrayal of Hasidic men used as drug couriers.
A mature, dialogue- and character-driven dramedy with a Michael Douglas performance to die for.
A horror movie that looks more like a photographed play with a one-dimensional insane surgeon and shallow victims.
A biting broadside attack on mindless consumerism.
This actors' exercise has all the limitations of a filmed play.
Not a single false note in this story of women's vulnerabilities, loneliness, seeking, disappointments, all brought about by the adoption conventions.
A dialogue- and character-driven whimsical tale that boasts a solid re-creation of the old South.
A dull tale told against off-putting photography.
Sizzling chemistry cannot overcome the banal script.
A thoroughly entertaining, partly fictionalized story featuring performances by blues artists associated with Chess Records.
The white-trash Strobbe family is investigated with both ribaldry and poignance.
A typical tale of grieving but with luminous acting.
Heady stuff, but plot feels forced rather than organic.
Boldly imaginative with a shot taken at weapons dealers.
This insightful documentary takes its place among all features that call upon us to be ourselves, to 'come out' and help prove to all that nobody's perfect.
Cliches abound: frantically edited fights, gore, lethargically acted
Overflowing with ethnic energy.
This Oscar-winning film deftly conflates a crime thriller with a smoldering romance.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A tense, elegant, intelligent thriller that will have audiences debating whether Liam Neeson's character is a serial killer or a kindly mortician.
A worthwhile trip down burlesque lane with the usual documentary bumps: too many talking heads at the expense of archival footage.
Delivers the visuals that the audience came for.
A slow-moving, painterly look at the condition of women in the Iran of 1953.
A simple story about a small-town French romance elevated by remarkable acting, clever dialogue, good music.
Wooden dialogue echoes across beautiful British Columbia.
Helen Mirren can make any movie more than tolerable including this soap.
More a reasonably absorbing domestic drama than a biopic of young John Lennon.
There's considerable originality in a story centering on a sperm donor whose identity and visits upend a household.
Limited by its claustrophobic set, 'Lebanon' offers a new view on the old theme that war is hell.
More an exhibition of precious acting than an absorbing narrative.
Displays a fertile imagination but is only marginally entertaining.
A minor work notable only for the strong performances of two non-professional actors.
Not as intense as the first episode but filled with sharp characterizations.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A well-acted, visceral story of an avaricious family that includes three Nazis and a serial killer.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Step aside, Sophocles. This Oedipal story is funny!
Casey Affleck's high, raspy voice almost sinks this violent film.
Tilda Swinton again proves herself one of the great actresses of her generation.
A broadside against the Mormon Church for helping to pass California's anti-gay Proposition 8, though some levity would increase its entertainment value.
Negotiating the Scottish Highlands, Mads Mikkelsen is scarier than the Loch Ness monster, but the film is a slog.
Doc proves that J.R. is still one of the funniest comedians we've got.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: America at its bleakest is on display in this hard-hitting look at hill people that does little to counter the stereotypes.
B-list Apatow with moments of laugh-out-loud hilarity.
About as scary and convincing as the haunted car ride at Coney Island.
An unpretentious, autobiographical movie exploiting the director's own experiences in the porn film industry.
Overlong, but fine ensemble performances highlight the tragic tale of a movie producer facing liquidation.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A cute slice-of-life about French residents who fumble and err but remain lovable despite their idiosyncracies.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An action-filled, emotional documentary that expresses hope that a divided people can be united through sports.
movie_title: After The Cup: Sons Of Sakhnin United (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary of this nature cannot provide the drama of a fiction movie, e.g. 'Babette's Feast,' but this is worth seeing if you believe that food should look at least as appealing as it tastes.
Shakespeare need not feel threatened by this movie, but 'Letters to Juliet' is nonetheless wholesome TV fare.
An over-the-top screwball comedy with a thunderous, sentimental conclusion.
A visually appealing blockbuster but one which mangles history and legend alike.
Expertly demonstrates the bumper sticker, 'Governments lie. Soldiers die.'
A sometimes plodding but often vibrant look at the fall and rise of Walt Disney Pictures
Claustrophobic and cinematic, humorous and ghoulish.
Horror, ballet, melodrama, Aronofsky, Natalie Portman...who can ask for more?
Exhausting, confusing and repetitious
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A survey course on the history of film criticism will introduce even professional critics to names that they do not already know and will be an eye-opener for all who want to know more about the background and current status of movie reviewers.
movie_title: For the Love of Movies: The Story of American Film Criticism (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An perceptive look at an Argentinian housewife into a world of puzzles.
A comic gem with an exquisitely photographed Paris forming an elegant backdrop.
Kristen Wiig is the funnist woman alive.
An exuberant product placement, if you will, for the city of Naples.
An embarrassing sitcom in need of a laugh-track as it is graced by nary a chuckle.
Virtually a special-effects miracle.
A virtually humorless tale of marital cheating.
Too twee to be effective.
Discount the diabetic-strong sweetness and you have a film that can convince everyone that education is fundamental.
A respectful documentary about the man who is arguably the greatest cinematographer of all time, Jack Cardiff.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Terrence Malick's visual delight, a career-culminating take on the mysteries of life.
Not as entertaining as the docs of Michael Moore and Morgan Spurlock but a must-see if we want to be healthy.
The self-absorbed teen's voiceovers are annoying and the movie's quirkiness is overdone.
One of the better pics from Hollywood but you won't want to run away to join this circus.
An astonishing performance by Shinobu Terajima anchors this indictment of right-wing Japanese nationalism of the 1940s.
A grindhouse-style slasher pic lacking style and wit.
A compelling drama about a bank robber who steals because of a psychological compulsion rather for a love of money.
An intense, albeit one-sided, documentary on location during demonstrations by the Palestinians in the village of Budrus against Israeli encroachments.
An effective, low-key dramatization of the true story of a crop artist.
Redford displays a keen sense of history in unveiling a 19th century trial with current resonance.
Morgan Spurlock shows he can be as entertaining a documentary film-maker as Michael Moore.

movie_review_blurb: Unique in showing us cave drawings that few modern human beings have ever seen, but you have to put up with Werner Herzog's pretentious narration.
