movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An uneven tone and the feeling of too many cooks mars the finished product, but there are moments of beauty and real terror.
The start wobbles, but once boy and dragon connect, this becomes a thrilling flight.
A touching melodrama illuminated by a solid turn from Tatum.

Heigl and Kutcher make a cute enough couple, but a cringeworthy opening and ludicrous (even by the standards of the genre) ending mean that this is one to watch only when your brain is switched to the "off" position.

A worthy farewell that packs in as much action as its seven predecessors combined and manages not to stint on the emotional beats. Harry Potter leaves us as a quiet, bespectacled, corduroy-wearing hero for the ages.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: More purgatory than hellfire.
Funny and scary - and sometimes both at once - it lives up to the original, even if it fails to surpass it.

This is not a simple story of an uptight English woman induced to loosen up by those freedom-lovin' Yanks, but a delicate and brilliantly acted story of overcoming the past to embrace an uncertain future.
A tough, impactful film that offers a sometimes uncomfortable but always gripping examination of cause and effect.
Another chance to see Pixar's most dazzling premise, now spruced up with a third dimension.
Somewhere between the pop-culture deconstruction of Zombieland and the skewed romance of (500) Days Of Summer, this manages to make the apocalypse seem charming. Warm is the right word.
It has quirky charm and a tender heart, but the treacly sentiment may become wearisome.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An awkward mix of realist social drama and Statham actioner, this doesn't quite convince as either.
Rings with all the emotion and power of the source and provides a new model for the movie musical.
We don't.
Gru still has charm and kids will adore the Minions.
Apparently unable to decide whether to take its own mythology seriously or not, this is a mess of sculpted cheekbones and incoherent romance.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: For a long stretch of the second act the film feels like doing a long stretch, but Schwarzenegger's having a ball as Stallone goes through the motions.
Loveable - especially if you're as fond of a pun as we are - and extremely silly.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It admirably avoids many of the pitfalls of adapting this book, but seems to have lost some of the life and pace as well.
It's a rare film that can simultaneously crack you up and send a chill down your spine. Worth seeing - even for believers.
It will require no conspiring to make you fall for this one; Whedon and Shakespeare are a perfect match.
Even this charming cast struggle to bring life to an overlong story that has all the sizzle of leftover turkey.
Fans will be left on a high; other viewers will be confused but generally entertained by a saga whose romance is matched only by its weirdness.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An animation that never drags itself out of mediocrity despite the best efforts of gifted animator Tartakovsky.
Two charming leads don't make up for a comedy that just doesn't quite deliver the laughs it should.
It didn't really need the 3D, but it's still a stunning, glorious family film, with the third dimension or otherwise.
Interesting ideas and howling anger at the 1 percent drive the first half, but the Bonnie and Clyde stylings of the second feel a little rushed and strangely out of sync.
The plot's all over the place, but there are a lot of laughs and some strong action beats along the way.
An astonishing-looking adaptation that captures the setting of the book, and its darkness, wonderfully, but goes too far towards edgy in its quest to avoid the usual literary clich√©s.
It won't do anything to win over those not already partial to Tarsem's style, but it has more than enough blood, guts and glamour to satisfy - and Cavill looks like a superman.
The few weaknesses in the plot can be overlooked as The Vow makes for a wonderful - if a bit teary - romance that is brilliantly acted.
A heartwarming tale about man's best friend.
Smart, funny and really quite hot, this is worth a look no matter what you think of Charlie's Angels.
Shoddy 3D and flashy editing distract from the admittedly great dancing, but little else offers a particular reason to watch it.
If even a tenth of the care and attention lavished on the production design and action sequences had been afforded the script, this could have been an adventure of legendary proportions.
It's just not quite as much fun as it should be, despite Pearce's best efforts and some good chemistry with Grace.

The Notebook may have had us blubbing but since then Nicholas Sparks adaptions have offered thin pickings for cinemagoers. For all Efron's boyish charms, this one could be the most ordinary of the lot.
It benefits from a supernaturally engaging cast, but this treads too closely to the rom-com model to feel as smart or moving as Westfeldt's previous best.
Perhaps no more absurd than the Verhoeven version, but certainly less amusing.
These bosses cannot justify either murder or lasting comic memories, fatally compromising a farce that could have been great but ends up merely mediocre.
Kinetic and convincing, this uses a limited budget to thrilling effect, giving us a sort of X-Men-meets-Trainspotting twist. We hope a sequel follows this early promise.
Utterly stupid and full of lazy plotting and lazier dialogue, this is just idiotic enough to entertain on nights when you want to give your brain a rest.

The unlikely superhero of this film is the hamster, who brings the funny amid a flurry of weaker gags. But Bolt still has charm - it just won't hit with the adults the way the best animated films can.
It's interesting to see a film about religion in Ireland that doesn't also feature terrorism or sectarianism.
An intelligent thriller that effectively conveys the message that terrorism, even in apartheid-era South Africa, is rarely a black-and-white issue.
There's so much story here that the characters don't have quite enough room to breathe, but it's still a fascinating look at a time, and a man, worth remembering.
Kids will enjoy the colourful animation and fun characters, but adults will wish it all made a bit more sense.
Cheadle's finest hour and proof that Sandler can act. Funny, sad and flawed - like its characters.
The plot's a trippy, twisty mess, and it's far too long, but it looks fantastic and makes some bold choices in its execution. And once again Jack's back to save the day.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Looks like European animation is still light years behind the US and Japan. Thank goodness for Highmore and Farrow - if only the whole film had been live-action.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cross-generational borderline friendships are all the rage this Winter, but Venus this ain't.
It won't win new fans, but as Potter movies go, this is the most filmic of the lot, suspenseful and action-packed.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The set pieces make this well worth watching while director Goro Miyazaki shows he's truly his father's son.
Sparkle may not be an obvious bobby dazzler but seek it out and you'll be rewarded with a real gem.

An adaptation at least as good as the novel - complex, delicate and devastating. Gorgeous cinematography, a lilting score and near-faultless performances, under Wright's assured direction, make this the first contender for next year's Best Picture Oscar.
Feels like a Sunday night TV drama - and not a very good one at that.
The trailer suggests a cheery comedy but brace yourself for some darkness in this shaggy dog story.
Whilst William H. Macy is as rewarding as ever, this has not transferred well from the stage.
At heart, this is a simple Zen fable about love and death. In execution, it's a complex and gorgeous mini-epic with sterling performances from its two stars.
Sure to raise heckles in the tabloid press, this is complex, thought-provoking cinema.
A tragic tale of teen rebellion and misplaced faith, this is a sober and sobering account of a young girl's untimely end, made enthralling by great performances and restrained direction.
A couple of good chuckles can't redeem this sappy mess.
There's a good-hearted father and son tale at the heart of the madness here, but the surroundings are sometimes a little too silly for true greatness.
Garner may justify her reputation as an action woman, but fails to prove that sais matter.
It's a missed opportunity to make a great documentary, but still decent family entertainment, with awe-inspiring Antarctic scenery and some very cute stars.
The energy and rhythm keep it moving along gracefully.
The Wild roars back from a rocky opening act to a storming last reel, just managing to claw its way above comparisons with Madagascar.
Yet another Hollywood kids' film subscribing to the offensive stereotype that Britain is peopled with aristocrats who live on vast estates and are waited on by a devoted and subservient staff.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A mature and beautifully told tale of family and the ghosts that haunt us.
Good idea unsuccessfully realised with Ed Burns doing his best.
Powerful, intelligent and surprisingly entertaining, Gore presents a compelling case. You'll believe a film can change the world.
This smart and funny creation is not just wish-fulfilment for the ''Sex'' And The City generation -- it's a Wall Street for the 21st century.
Sadly confused, but some beautiful touches give this a magical feel.
Fatally lacking laughs and a real sense of adventure, this is a sporadically funny and awkwardly animated curiosity.
Proof positive that Wushu and Chan don't mix, this aims to create a new crossover genre but falls between two stools.
Small kids will love the waddlesome dancing and colourful animation, but older viewers will likely be disturbed by the story's darker elements.
Very patchy with an unconvincing lead character.
Spellbound director Jeffrey Blitz fails to recapture the magic of his spelling bee doc with his latest effort - despite the best efforts of the talented unknowns that make up the cast.
Not quite as smart as it wants to be, and a better action movie than it is a political thriller, this is still a heart-pounding drama.
Better than the silly second instalment and boasting an effectively creepy empty world setting, it's nevertheless scuppered by a lack of coherence.
Strong performances and a few laughs, but the story feels lazy next to superior efforts recently in the same genre.
Significantly better than the first film or, say, the first two Harry Potters.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Uplifting but never mawkish, and gorgeously shot.
As much Tolkien's baby as Mignola's, this has more heart and humour than most fantasy films can dream of. Hellaciously good.
Smart, incisive, but not as sharp as it should have been. With a subject this ripe for evisceration, it's a pity to let it off with flesh wounds.
Not as smart or as satirical as you might hope, but an enjoyable and often funny look at a mad, mad, mad, mad world.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It verges on so-bad-it's-good territory, but just isn't entertaining enough. Lacking in tension and pace, poorly edited and starring wholly unsympathetic characters, this is just dull, drab and boring.
If you're under 12, you won't be disappointed. If you're over 12, the fact this is as funny and bright as it is insipid won't stop you from avoiding it like the plague.
While its tone occasionally wavers and there are some wobbly performances, this has moments of true lightness, and a welcome sense of whimsy often missing in the costume genre.
A well-acted and tightly structured piece that would be more impactful if there weren't a feeling that we've seen it before.
Disappointing. Stone whipped this out in time for the US Presidential election, but it's hard to see how it'll make any significant impact on voters. Or why it even should.
Witherspoon works hard to convince us otherwise, but this is a miscast mess. Definitely a turkey rather than a Christmas pudding.
A remake that does not disgrace the original, this is sufficiently different to stand alone and just as relevant in its concerns - as well as succeeding (arguably better) as a thriller.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The laughs come few and far between in a story as drab as the Northern skies under which it is set.
The music's great, if predictable, and the talented young cast give it their all. We just wish that Cera would try something new.
The acting is excellent.
Whilst missing a trick in terms of script and casting, at least they've amped up the action from the somewhat sedate book.
There are a couple of effective scares, but this feels like a retread too far. Enough with J-horror already - let's do something new.
The monochrome animation is stark and beautiful, and Marjane's an appealing narrator. Often hilarious, sometimes tragic, this may be low-tech, but it's high-class.
Off-the-shelf teen fantasy not likely to satisfy the post-Potter/LOTR crowd but guaranteed to enrage fans of the source novel. The newly added quasi-religious overtones don't help either.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One of the better British comedies we've seen this year.
A smart, accessible, surprisingly balanced look at our dysfunctional world. Compelling stuff.
If Wedding Crashers is in your top ten rom-coms ever, you might not hate this. Otherwise, it's too gross to be sweet and too sweet to be gross.
There's terrific chemistry between the leads, but an episodic structure set over 20 years is too sprawling to really allow for a connection.
There are a few effective jump scares but the dodgy acting and an appalling ending marks this out as an interesting first try rather than an indie breakaway hit.
Beautiful but boring.
Brando gives his all but just ends up becoming himself. Interesting for it's historical notoriety, but overlong and dull in places.
Bleak, brutal and quite possibly brilliant, this is a triumphant return to form for Lumet and further proof that Hoffman is on an incredible winning streak.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Uncompromising, intelligent and searing cinema.
Too scattershot to land any effective punches.
Light on facts but heavy on bombast, this is a stirring tribute to a doomed generation.
This is the Scat Pack's first definitive miss and it just scrapes two stars on the strength of Wilson's best efforts. But for God's sake, give this man a sparring partner next time he's on screen.
A strangely affecting romance with real heart - and another sign that Gosling is one of the best young actors around.
It just scrapes two stars on the strength of Wilson's best efforts. But for God's sake, someone give this man a sparring partner.
Strong performances from the young cast make a compelling case that the US govt is failing its soldiers, but the film's a little too much of a blunt instrument.
Nearly as good as the last film - the starrier cameos compensating somewhat for the more scattershot plot - this is fun but could have been more deeply felt.
Tess Morris' smart script and Ben Palmer's assured direction largely hold the interest, making this more pleasure than ordeal -- and therefore a rarity in British romantic comedies.
The thoughtful translation from the Broadway boards to the cinema screen and well-chosen leads makes this for a better than average adaptation.
It's a little too long, but holds the attention thanks to Lane's charisma, Ryan's breathtaking cinematography and the dizzying power of young love.

Comparisons to Reservoir Dogs are probably inevitable given the warehouse setting, copious firearms and endlessly quotable script, but this is a sleeker and more violent film (though perhaps less sadistic).

There's a point in every Reacher book... where the case seems unsolvable. This film never finds that point -- and worse, you'll be screaming the answer at Reacher through a key third-act scene while he thinks furiously.
Happily, it's [Marvel 's] most impressive visual film yet.
Yeon has come up with a take on zombies that is rooted deep in the genre but still feels innovative.
With this heavy lifting done, there's every reason to hope for an even more magical adventure next time.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's not the worst of the trilogy, but this is less for fans of thrillers and more for people who are pining after last year's holiday to Florence.
Quiet, thoughtful and deeply human, this is one of Jarmusch's finest and features Adam Driver's best performance yet - although you do risk coming out with a new affection for modernist poetry.
Much of the book's subtlety survives the translation. And the substance, for anyone with even a passing interest in philosophy and theology, is fascinating, valuable and timely.
The good news is that it's something genuinely fresh, a Star Wars story unlike any big screen adventure yet.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Better than you could have predicted given the title but squarely aimed at a young and undiscerning audience.
It's a time-fractured but close-focused look at the bereaved First Lady, and thanks to Natalie Portman's performance as the fragile, ferocious Jackie, it's one of the strongest dramas of the year.
In these troubled times, we could do worse for a hero than a man who put his enlistment papers where his mouth is and saved scores of lives.
The ending isn't quite as metaphysically satisfying as The Lego Movie, but in terms of jokes per minute, this may score even higher.
It glides romantically along on the surface while political turmoil boils away underneath. Its plea for tolerance isn't subtle, but it's a story that deserves to be told.
This is still a scary film, but the more Winguard shows, the less frightening it becomes -- and it leans on a few too many horror clich√©s instead of subverting them.
The best zombie-ish apocalypse in years. Sennia Nanua is a major discovery, but it's the dense social commentary and moral dilemmas that will haunt you.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's well designed and shot, but in service of a story that never coalesces into something intelligent or compelling.
Bad taste can be hilarious, shaking a laugh from even the most reserved, and opening minds to new worlds. But there are also tastes so bad they just make you retch.
It's a fascinating look at modern journalism - but perhaps not always for the reasons its makers intended.
Its fizzy, meandering, ultimately plotless-plot will frustrate many, but if you just go with it this is one of the most joyous films you will ever see.
It just wears you down and wears you out, making you wonder if there was ever such a thing as a hero anyway. Let them pummel each other if they must; just leave us out of it.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to the extraordinary engineering work of screenwriters Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely and directors Anthony and Joe Russo, this film keeps moving, never losing its sense of purpose.
The more the film harks back to other X-instalments, the more you'll wish you were watching those instead.
While there's something admirable in Jones's steadfast adherence to naff fantasy tropes, it makes no concession to fans of realism.

While this is utter nonsense for much of its runtime, overstuffed with people you will struggle to care about, and while its finale shamelessly begs a sequel, there's still a (molten) core of wild entertainment beneath the hokum.
It's scatty, scrappy and thoroughly OTT, but then that's like the characters themselves.
This feels far more fresh than it has any right to do, simply because it's casually feminist, unfailingly pacy and finds an exact mid-point between razor sharp and pleasingly dumb comedy.
Triple 9 trips over its own lofty ambitions.

All the elements of a solid drama are here, yet in trying to overplay every single one of them Landesman winds up diminishing the whole, reaching for importance but coming away with a handful of adequacy.
If you're a fan, you should offer thanks to the prophets of Bajor, because Star Trek is back on form.
The film lives or dies on Margot Robbie's Harley Quinn, and that's a problem, because Ayer doesn't know what to do with her -- or any of his female cast.
A fiercely original, pleasantly unpredictable character piece. This is a gang of outsiders with something valuable to say about the world we live in.
With different battalions arrayed in brightly coloured, beautifully constructed armour it's as elegantly constructed a fantasy as anything Zhang has ever done.

If it had been more elegant in its storytelling, it could have been a fun genre crossover, but the best efforts of Steers and his cast can't turn the overstuffed book into a film that makes any real sense.
Huppert has always been good, but she's never been better than this. Often shocking, surprisingly funny and strangely powerful, this is intense and fascinating.
If there were more African-American directors working in Tinseltown, this film's plot would surely be familiar. As it is, it's quite unlike anything else out there.
Olshefski captures the frustration, resignation and determination that leaves you struck by this family -- average in their concerns but extraordinary in their dedication to one another.
A tired retread of better jokes in the first two movies, this drags along to an admittedly heartwarming conclusion.
It may not be quite the greatest show on Earth, but Gracey, Jackman and the entire cast are deeply committed to entertaining and leave you feeling an old-school musical thrill.
It's an intriguing look into a secret world and a great performance from Chastain, but Sorkin's directorial debut never quite makes the leap from great poker movie to great movie.
Pixar has raised the animation bar again, with its most musical - and arguably most magical - film yet. If this is the afterlife we're all headed to, don't fear the reaper.
It may not set the world alight - ironically, given the solar flare that started its story's disaster - but it ‚Ä®will get the blood pumping.
Unless you have tiny, religious children, it's probably best to avoid it.
Robbie and Janney are flawless in a compelling and corrective account of a misunderstood figure; one of the more darkly funny biopics you'll ever see.
Given it could be re-titled 'Microaggressions: The Movie', this is an unsurprisingly upsetting watch at times, but it's made compelling by Vega's dignified, heartfelt performance.
Delivers all the undemanding laughs you could wish, and has such a plot of such baroque intricacy that it even manages a few genuine shocks.
A life story packed with incident means that this sometimes rushes past events that would be formative for anyone else, but equally means that Lamarr's life story is never, ever dull.
This spectacular adventure sometimes wanders across the borders of invention into artificiality, but finds its feet when it focuses in on its characters and their relationships.
Winslet's stunning turn is worth a look if you can stand the consciously stagey feel.

Smart, tough and a little bit cool, this is an intriguing opening rather than a slam-dunk in its own right, but the cast - and especially Woodley - make it sufficiently diverting to merit a place in the action franchise ranks.
It's a promising set-up, but the story is profoundly predictable.
It'll entertain you while on the verge of a turkey coma, but it will never rank among the Christmas classics.
Vibrant and brimming with vitality, this is empathic towards its subjects but fiercely critical of the system that victimises them.
A family adventure that's the right sort of heartwarming, delivering real human emotion through the medium of a small bear.
Brainless action comedies are one of the great pleasures in cinema, but only when they're crafted with more care and intelligence than this.
Too restrained and polite to really grip the attention, this feels more like comfortable Sunday night TV than cinematic fare.
An informative but incomplete look at Whitney Houston's life and death, this will frustrate fans as much as it fascinates them.
Well-meaning and sometimes emotional, this is often too low-key for its own good, and might have benefited from a little more traditional documentary context and shape.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.
It's cool and brutal, but with such impressive action credentials you almost wish there were fewer plot devices to distract you as Charlize gets up and at 'em.
Elba is genuinely great as the tormented Roland, but the film does its best to suffocate him under a mountain of plot-heavy nonsense. Disappointing.
It's loud, at times unwatchably gross and sometimes lingers on the verge of hysteria. But it's also a warm-hearted and optimistic celebration of black womanhood. Maybe friendship can save us all.

The fourth film in the Conjuring Universe, Annabelle: Creation is well performed, but the rhythm of the scares feels slightly off. Characters scream when they should be quiet and whimper when they should be hollering their heads off.
Loud, silly and tired. Aside from an almost-fun Jackie Chan cameo, this is enough to give anyone a severe nut allergy.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This feels like a dated echo of better films like 'Madagascar' and 'Kung Fu Panda'.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Frenetic, kinetic action meets satisfyingly soapy drama. See it before everyone tries to copy the best bits.
The whole thing reads as an indictment of the sort of upper class upbringing that Milne's children's books idealised, with only paid employees offering worthwhile parental affection.
Atmospheric and startlingly well performed by the cast, this is a compelling character study. Daphne may find people largely annoying, but there's inspiration in her determination to find her way.

Faris and Dayton are interested in how the players got there, not in the game itself, and their emphasis on the whole environment of the match creates a far richer and chewier film than the usual triumphant sports drama.

Fatally, the director never spends time on any of the characters who fill the screen -- and while no sensible person goes to a monster movie for deep human drama, you need at least a sprinkling to make it work.

It's fun to see Zoolander once more. It seems unlikely that the premise could ever sustain a third film, but if this is Derek's swan song then he leaves amid a flurry of feathers and bustle -- surely all a male model could wish for.
There's a hint of comforting, chocolate-box, Sunday-night TV here, but it's delivered via such quietly powerful performances and with such hope that it's hard to resist.
Witty, absurd and far more entertaining than it has any right to be, this could finally shed light on the financial crisis for those of us who found it all too boring to contemplate.
Inside Out is most decidedly Pixar at its best.
It is fun and frothy and convinces as a worthy part of the Marvel canon.
This is too scattershot to maintain its hilarity for anything more than a moment, and too mean-spirited to hold the attention beyond that laugh.
Maybe the inevitable sequel will be a little more thoughtful, though the chances of that seem low.
Cavill and Hammer are made for each other, but the film can't always find the pyrotechnics to match their chemistry.
Trevorrow never quite finds the moments that made the first film so transcendent.
Christopher McQuarrie steps in with a thriller that mixes old-fashioned spy movie tropes with state-of-the-art action beats and a rich helping of wit.
The glitzy surface has overtaken any meaning that the show might occasionally have snuck in.
Ian McKellen's incarnation in this latest film somehow manages to unite Sherlocks old and new, adding a hint of that unpredictable modern flair to the more traditional 19th century remnant.

It is no exaggeration to say that this could become the new Big Lebowski -- something that will not just stand up to repeat viewings but positively reward every single rewatch of its twisted, lunatic glory.
Those of you who usually avoid musicals like the plague, in other words, should not be so quick to judge this one.
This may be bereft of the bombast that Americans expect from their spy adventures, but as a modern spin on a John Le Carr√©-style thriller, it's a stylish and smart action film.
Shot entirely in Farsi, in a desert town in California, it is both realistic and fantastical, foreign and familiar.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: C√©dric Jimenez has clearly studied the Scorsese playbook. There's much of the same fluidity of storytelling here, the same rich, jewel-like colours, the same glamorous setting and crime-fuelled hedonism. But he isn't just another wannabe.
If you can bear it, this hipster horror film of creeping social dread is utterly hilarious.
Despite the best efforts of the cast, whatever good nugget of an idea in there just can't stretch to a whole film.
It's all awfully charming and wittily scripted, and almost enough to cover the fact that very little in the way of action takes place.
Heller's nimble direction and clever script, based on Phoebe Gloeckner's semi-autobiographical graphic novel, ensure that the film never paints either Minnie or Monroe entirely as victim or predator.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A grown-up film about serious people that mercifully escapes any awards-grabbing platitudes, this is more thrilling than most action movies.
The story's slight, but it's still an exhilarating look at an unlikely group of heroes, scored and edited for maximum effect.
At times terrifying and too tough for tinies, this is nevertheless a triumphant sequel that puts its faith in Hiccup and Toothless to find a way through dark times for man and dragon.
Maybe we do deserve another Twister, but to showcase the advances in effects since you really need a bigger budget than this.
Strong performances keep the viewer guessing as much as our heroine, but the character drama recedes as the thriller element builds, to its detriment.
It's a well-made adventure with great energy and considerable style, but it's essentially a maze without an exit.
Madame Bovary breathes life into a classic story, with a delicate hand and a careful eye.
Sweet and good-hearted, this feels like a throwback to family comedies of the '80s.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The drama and tone are powerful and effective and Lawrence makes an exceptionally charismatic heroine, but an almost total lack of action means this is less catching fire than treading water.
Both heavy-handed and ham-fisted, this is a self-important morality tale where you can see everyone's uppance coming long before it arrives.
A compassionate and inspiring look at an extraordinary life, anchored by two of the best performances of the year.
Once you swallow the giant pill that is the premise, it just about makes sense, and Woodley sells it with all her conviction.
Branagh pulls off the same sort of trick he did with Thor: he creates a visually overwhelming, heavily gilded world, and then keeps the focus on the characters within it.
Bigger and, yes, darker than the first, this is less air-punchingly gleeful but probably more consistent.
Gripping, humane and lighter than it sounds, Stewart's first foray into directing suggests that he was right to quit the day job. We can't wait to see what he does next.
Bitingly funny, deeply strange and hauntingly melancholic.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film that unfolds with every re-watch and reveals more subtle little grace notes.
Jaw-droppingly beautiful when it isn't horrifyingly ugly, this is a literal vision of hell-on-wheels and features some of the most astonishing action ever committed to film.
Much of the hilarity in these films -- and they really are very funny -- comes from watching the excess as characters try to outdo one another's manliness.
Given that the closest Meyers has had to a real plot with forward momentum in over a decade is The Holiday, it might be time to bring in a co-writer.
A visually sumptuous, deliciously over-the-top helping of grand guignol playfulness.
These two men, unlikely allies and even less likely heroes, make this a character study worth seeing -- if your nerves can bear it.
It's never Quantum-levels of disappointing, but it all just feels overcooked.

We already have one American Psycho, and sadly for this adaptation of John Niven's book there was no need for a matching British Psycho, even one based in a different industry and played by a hot young thing.
Its epic sweep, grand designs and unyielding central performance make this a compelling finale.
Better to view it as a fiction, a what-might-have-been study in hubris and vision and human failings. In those terms, it's quietly fascinating, and only one of those two words really fits Steve Jobs.
It's a film full of obvious allusions to played-out concepts.
Just as he did in Speed and The Matrix, Reeves has found a way to take an action genre and do it just a little bit better than everyone else.
The script was semi-improvised, which often shows in the film's loose, mildly chaotic tone, but it also allows the three charismatic stars to riff easily together.
Acerbic, unexpected and quietly heart-warming without ever approaching sappy, this takes a no-nonsense approach to big issues - life, love and ageing - and never feels heavy-handed.

This is the sort of accomplished indie film that we have been missing the last few years, one that couldn't be made in the mainstream but which tells a recognisable, important human story without feeling preachy.
If you were to make a list of the essential ingredients of a Star Wars film, you would find almost all in J.J. Abrams' wake-up call to this sleeping giant of a franchise.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Bloody gore - seriously bloody -frequent flashes of humour and that beautifully claustrophobic staging make this a wintery winner despite its shortcomings.
if you can stomach a little raw bison liver and ignore a deluge of irrelevant Oscar hype, this is a wilderness expedition worth taking.
The Martian is [Ridley Scott's] most entertaining effort in years, and perhaps his most big-hearted film ever.
It's so beautifully shot -- by the incomparable Roger Deakins -- and subtly directed by Villeneuve that it feels fresh even when occasionally going through familiar beats.
Howard's story is too wide, too sweeping. The characters are mere sketches, and never seem as real as the sea-spray.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This rarely goes deep enough to make for a true character piece.

Audiences willing to wade knee deep in the muck and mire of the human abyss are advised to seek out Humanit√© at the local arthouse.
The jail setting is eye-opening, Gibson is on good form and a tight narrative grips until events become too farcical towards the end.
The performances are strong, especially from Patel and Syal, and there are plenty of laughs.
Nothing much happens until a preposterously contrived and melodramatic climax.

Consistently amusing, with a several laugh-out-loud set-pieces, including a classic scene aboard a tourist helicopter over Manhattan, the picture makes for a riotous and inspired comedy that doesn't outstay its welcome at a tight 84 minutes long.
Gone is the spark that made the relationship between the exuberant Smith and buttoned-up Jones so much fun.
The action is very well staged but it's no substitute for genuine suspense.
The costumes and production design are first class but Dark Shadows is only a must-see for Burton devotees.
It's never hugely funny or moving - Anderson's movies are too stylised and detached for that - but it has charm and a lovely performance from Willis as a weary local cop who's never found true love.
The Woody Allen-ish romantic strivings of the original film are replaced by family bickering as everyone goes at each other in the cramped apartment, to diminishing effect or purpose.
The massive body count is no compensation for a coherent story or memorable action.
After this reunion the only kindly option is retirement.
Pure fairytale escapism that doesn't boast any digital trickery, celebrity voiceovers or unnecessary action.
The six folk-like tales featuring dragons, witch doctors and a talking horse have a whimsical charm and are beautifully designed but - watched all at once - may leave younger children fidgeting.
It's well acted but repetitive and not scary enough.
Narrated by Patrick Stewart, this is beautifully shot if a tad toothless. Nothing to upset tots.
It's finely acted (both Close and McTeer were Oscar nominated) and McTeer brings some welcome heart and humour.

Whedon maintains just the right tone of affectionate spoofery - the bickering never too silly or annoying - and gives all the characters, including Jeremy Renner's newcomer Hawkeye, enough to do to feel integral to proceedings.
A dull B-movie with ideas above its station.
The off-beat sensibility may appeal to some but I found it torture.
You should expect the unexpected and that's what we get as a traditional horror movie set up gives way to some droll, increasingly bonkers post-modern nonsense...
It's rather more watchable than you might expect because it wears its idiocy on its sleeve and is, at times, quite funny.
Will love blossom? Will you care? What's the point?
Hicks coats everything in a treacly glow that suffocates any sign of life, least of all from the cast.
Favouring pratfalls over wit and insight, the picture offers only occasional respite in a "dudes group" of dads who meet in the park with their offspring, led by Chris Rock.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Another likeable but uneven comedy in the vein of Looking For Eric, [Loach's] 2009 film starring Eric Cantona.
The nonsense logic rather undermines the portentous tone of the whole thing but luckily, after a rather laboured first hour, the picture gets on with the business of scaring us.
Poignant, touching and inspiring, even if it doesn't tell you quite as much as you'd like to know about Sixto Rodriquez, to give him his full name.
It's handsome looking but stilted and pointless.
Younger children should be satisfied.
For a summer superhero movie The Dark Knight Rises is thrillingly ambitious and serious-minded.
Enhanced considerably by Vangelis's stirring score - has a film ever owed so much to its music? - the picture also works as a poignant paen to youthful hopes and the passing of time.
Carell and Knightley do their best to make it lively and touching but the characters are, by turns, dull and irritating, and I never really believed in or cared about their relationship.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The story and character development are rather perfunctory but there are some good lines and there's no faulting the animation, showcased in some spectacular action sequences.
The cast are terrific. McConaughey's a law unto himself as the semi-crazed ringmaster and he gets his own show-stopping moment on stage.
The Hunter is a taut, thought-provoking and ultimately touching drama with wonderful work from Dafoe, O'Connor and Sam Neill as a local guide with conflicted loyalties.
Eye-opening and hugely entertaining, with a stirring score, the picture is a well-timed poke-in-eye for the contemptuous rich.

Snow White proves a decent swashbuckler at the climax, the picture looks impressive and it's appealing young cast should ensure it has more chance of catching on with the public than the lame Mirror, Mirror.
An explicit comedy drama about infidelity comprising nine short films.
Not especially original but surprisingly effective.
The acting in Your Sister's Sister is also top-notch and reason enough to see it, especially if you're a fan of the lovely Emily Blunt.
It's hardly a relatable scenario but there's something compelling about it all the same as these two not wholly sympathetic characters try and have their cake and eat it.
Affection for the characters carries the day ... and with its high caliber cast the prospect of a sequel is not unwelcome.
The story is borderline inconsequential but the characters are lively and engaging and the performances strong.
It's exciting, witty and very well-cast with some memorable set-pieces and a tight, suspenseful plot.
It's honest, mature and insightful but also fun, silly and touchingly romantic.
A second-rate horror from Paranormal Activity writer Oren Peli.
It's an amiable enough alternative to the summer's special effects blockbusters. Just don't expect a wild time.
Directed by Regan Hall, this is benign, family-friendly fare (not as cool, edgy or sexy as I anticipated) and a cheerful enough warm up to the Olympics.
A twisted, well acted and quite compelling comedy of errors, until a brutal, over-extended finale leaves a very sour taste.
Behind the cold calculation of the narrative lies a warm heart and an uplifting message about love. See it before the Hollywood remake.
Fincher delivers a seedily compulsive glimpse into a cold, brutal universe seething with twisted passions, even if the story is little more than a slick, sick potboiler.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's inconsequential, campy fun but a sharper and funnier script would have made it more memorable and entertaining.
Horror fans may find the picture too old-school but it was nightmarishly effective for me.

Directed by Jason Reitman, this is original, bracing and darkly comic with a strong performance from Theron but it's not as funny or psychologically probing as it should be and there's no escaping the fact Mavis is pretty grim company.
It's not as exciting as it should be but picks up towards the end and Ed Harris is fun as a property tycoon nasty.
When it comes to being stuck in an apartment, Polanski still knows how to make an audience squirm.
An exuberant race-against-time adventure in an exotic world of outsize bugs and reptiles, gamely performed by a likable cast, especially Johnson and Caine who spar amusingly.
Suspenseful, memorable, thought-provoking and psychologically credible, brilliantly acted all round.
Finely acted and partly improvised, the picture captures nicely the highs and lows of first love. It's less fun but more truthful than a standard rom-com.
Not as laugh-out-loud funny or as overtly moving as you might expect, but with an underlying honesty and authenticity that make the characters linger long in the memory.
While offering the requisite tension and thrills, it is quite unsparingly bleak and realistic for this kind of thing and benefits from superior characterization.
The picture is as laboured as its short-breathed protagonist.
It's slick entertainment rather than deeply profound but it works.
A breathless, bone-crunching espionage thriller distinguished by its female protagonist, Mallory Kane, played by mixed martial arts star Gina Carano.
The picture has many fine qualities and is a rewarding watch...
A pointless and pretentious oddity.
Like The Social Network it grippingly dramatizes a dry, seemingly impenetrable subject that has huge implications for the way we live.
A giant yawn that proves once again that sex as a cinematic subject is one colossal turn-off.
With Moscow-emptied out, a la London in 28 Days Later, it is visually impressive but plodding and silly.
Poignant and touching though it is in places, I can't help feeling Thatcher and her family would find this portrayal invasive and cruel while the factual accuracy seems highly debatable.
There's pleasure and humour to be had in observing these troubled characters (and fine performers) as they navigate intimidating, unfamiliar territory...
It's pitched as a comedy and has a few left-field laughs but is as empty-headed as its protagonist.
Not only does the food look barely edible but the film is remarkably unilluminating about the history of the restaurant, the characters or those who ate there.
Cruise's conviction and sheer sweat carries the day.
There's no escaping the weaknesses of the play: Coriolanus is a bit of a chump and the story holds few surprises.
Witty, affectionate and charmingly silly.
Gripping, funny and uplifting with some lively characters...

All this is relayed in flashback and the storytelling is a tad episodic but it's exuberantly told, with some engaging characters and colourful visuals. Dog-lovers may even find themselves wiping away a tear or two.
Tom Conti is good value as a fleet-footed bar owner and the dance sequences are vigorously staged but the story is plodding and perfunctory and has no connection with the earlier film...
This is a quintessential Aardman production that's as hopelessly endearing as the Pirate Captain himself: well out-of-sync with the mainstream and quite bonkers.
It's a great idea but there are too many confusing sup-plots and no satisfactory resolution.
The effects are impressive but wasted in the service of a silly, so-what story.
Directed with flair by Fletcher, Wild Bill is more affecting family drama than conventional gangster pic and it's an outstanding achievement.
One can forgive the political simplicity and stilted performances, much less excusable is the unexciting plot, run-of-the-mill action and non-existent characterization.

The sheer spectacle, horror and ghoulishness of the scenario holds the attention and the story moves fast as we journey with Katniss from her impoverished mining town to the glittering, futuristic capital city where the contest is staged.
Kate Beckinsale is wasted as his wife and a smug ending leaves a slightly sour taste but a well cast Wahlberg carries the day.

There's some good comedy as their expectations of school life are turned on their head (everyone's caring and politically correct) and Tatum's hunk finds himself bonding with the science nerds, while Hill's fatty is cast as Peter Pan.
Largely avoiding the dangers of an episodic narrative the picture grips throughout and isn't as claustrophobic as you might expect, with plenty of drama occurring up top.
The picture may be too wholesome and twee for fans' of the director's edgier work like Almost Famous but it deserves to be a big hit with families.
The cast has charm, and some of lines raise a chuckle, but the story lacks pace, plausibility and surprise.
The picture is handsomely staged and easy-on-the-eye but never establishes a fluent pace or tone, while the general point of the story escaped me.
It looks fantastic and youngsters may find the exotic universe compelling enough but the result is sadly soulless and unexciting.
Cusack is fine as Poe but let down by a routine script that doesn't conjure up a character of great intrigue.
Could have been a British 24 but is undone by terrible plotting, implausibility and lack of excitement.
It feels like the pilot for a dated nineties sitcom, just not one I'd like to watch. Where are Aniston's friends when she needs them?
In some respects the picture tries too hard to be too many different things, and Driver's Viv feels underwritten, but the nostalgic, toe-tapping atmosphere and likeable characters carry the day.
McG fails to conjure up any exciting or original set-pieces so it falls flat as an action film.
An absorbing if flawed thriller set in Buenos Aires...
A safe bet for Bourne fans.

There's a refreshing, amusing and touching candour to the picture's portrayal of its oldies in crisis. It turns out they have the same problems as people half their age - just with a different perspective.
It's always a pleasure to watch Woody Harrelson when he's giving one of his meaty performances and he's on good form in Rampart but boy does his character, and the film, test our patience.
A timeless epic that gets me every time (yes, I needed my own life raft at the screening), the power of the storytelling and the performances by Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio grip throughout.
There's some lively slapstick that young children should enjoy but little story to speak of and too many lame gags.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey looks like the start of another blockbuster trilogy.

The British rom-com is back!
It's a little frantic at times but great fun, clever and well-crafted.
Some of the plotting is a little neat and simplistic but this is finely-made, adult filmmaking that makes you think.

A thoughtful and thought-proving picture.

A creaky, lethargic and daft action thriller ...
It's tender, humane and funny and superbly acted; a simple but affecting parable about experiencing life to the fullest.

[An] exciting, imaginative and very likable adventure.
C'est magnifique.
A sophisticated romantic drama in which love blossoms - with many complications - far below the surface.
Elegantly diverting entertainment with a handsome cast who effortlessly inhabit their stylish period tailorings.
A charming, beautifully acted character comedy that proves you're never too old to say "never".

Just as ghastly as it sounds.
Shows you don't need much more than a good script to make a decent film - even if said script involves time travel.
Lee maintains a very precise balance between the wondrous and the outrageous so we are never taken for fools in swallowing this tall tale - it might just be true.
Reacher fans will probably be happy enough with this debut outing for their hulking hero.
An arresting, both barrels blazing return to form.
The picture moves fast and is an efficient enough action-horror, with good effects and plenty of violence, but it's too machine-tooled and perfunctory to make you care.

It doesn't really ring true but it's fun and well performed.

A very entertaining sequel that recaptures the fun and charm of the first film after the cacophonous excesses of Iron Man 2.

A riveting but depressing history of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
What's not to like? Unfortunately, quite a lot.

There are some good ideas here, just not enough frights.

movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The picture's really about the trials and joys of performing for a living so it's no surprise that it has attracted such a fine cast, nor that its principal virtue lies in the acting.

An engaging bit of myth-making, if a little undisciplined like its protagonist.

Johnson is charismatic and personable but deserves better than this lame and unexciting picture.
Disappointing.
The real crime here is the waste of comic talent.

A very satisfying, entertaining and thought-provoking thriller.

[A] shocking, brilliantly put together film ...
If you're in the mood for something raucous, rude and very silly, Ted should keep you entertained. Just be warned: Toy Story it 'aint.
The plot won't surprise but it's fun and freaky in equal measure.
A sweet, safe bet to entertain young girls over Christmas.

movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The stop-start narrative fails to build momentum and tension and there are no stand-out action scenes, although Neeson is as commendably straight-faced and determined as ever.

If the plot was tighter, more involving and suspenseful you might overlook the ludicrous swagger of the whole thing but the story is a run-of-the-mill yarn about bank robbers that never much grips or convinces. It's also too long.
It's fun but a light on plot and not quite funny enough.
When cinemas are stuffed with juvenile comedies it's a great treat to watch one that is aimed at grown-ups and treats its audience as such.
An efficient but rather redundant London-set remake of the cult 1996 Danish drug thriller directed by Nicolas Winding Refn.
None of the storylines are very funny or have any notable bearing on one another.

Lawless is extremely well made, stylish and evocative of the era and it's far from chew-your-knuckles dull. However, its artistic pretensions fail to jazz up what is a very familiar and straightforward story.

Its very Blair Witch-lite, serving up a thin smattering of urban legend with only a few scares towards the end.
Made on a low-budget this is cheap and cheerful but spirited, witty and warm-hearted.

The plotting may be a tad unconvincing at times but the performances are outstanding.
A serviceable action thriller elevated by the presence of William Fichtner as a CIA agent leading the manhunt.
Even more melodramatic, badly written and poorly acted than Twilight: Breaking Dawn.
Slow but absorbing and finely performed.

movie_review_blurb: However, old-fashioned and rather simplistic it requires a certain indulgence, much like Gus himself.
The years most entertaining animation.

Srong on character and atmosphere but weak on story and excitement.

Quite watchable, sustained by the mechanics of an intriguing murder plot rather than convincing human drama.

An absorbing, sensitive drama that feels painfully, and often amusingly, true.

movie_review_blurb: You'll never see Swan Like in quite the same light again.
Packed with sci-fi in-jokes, the picture is more gently amusing than hilarious and the characters, while likeable, are hardly the most fascinating or complex.

Satisfying, grown-up entertainment.

A shocking and brilliant film.

A confusing and rather daft Japanese mystery/horror yarn...
Pathetic.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A hit, a very palpable hit.
Daft and dull.
These days the bad guys have all the fun.
The setting constantly diverts, supplying some terrific sights and sounds (there are some rousing, samba-inspired dance numbers) and it's made with considerable affection, zest and good humour.

A first feature that is far from perfect but has its heart in all the right places.

A harrowing, unflinching epic.

Magical storytelling that makes perfect family entertainment for the Easter holidays.

A very promising, if depressing, first feature.
