movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is a stylish record of that tour and an insight into what motivates this quixotic pair of rockers.
movie_title: The White Stripes Under Great White Northern Lights (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's all overwrought and unpersuasive.

It's a high-concept twist too far: in Liar Liar and Groundhog Day, the worlds themselves were believable; whereas here the world (explained via a cumbersome opening voiceover) is simply too far-fetched and therefore lacks resonance.
You have to keep reminding yourself that The Blind Side is based on real events. It seems much more like a cannily concocted, sugar-coated fairytale designed to inspire and uplift.
It perhaps fizzles out towards the end but otherwise zips along very engagingly. The only challenge for the target audience will be finding the time to see it.
The Rebound offers up surprisingly nice characters (too nice, you could argue) and a modest charm that compensates for a lack of big laughs or much suspense.
The Town is very professionally crafted, grown-up and exciting entertainment. How often does a critic get to write those words?
If your taste is for exploitation-style B-movies with an abundance of decapitations then director Robert Rodriquez's Machete is for you...
Anyone who has invested in the trilogy will savour the mixture of dread and anticipation as the cat-and-mouse game reaches a stirring conclusion.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An unexpected pleasure, bringing some punchy Hollywood professionalism to a traduced genre.
The story about a family of cannibals thrown into confusion after the death of daddy cannibal (who will lead? who will hunt?) is pretentious, slow and deadly dull.
Aftershock is a gruelling and sombre watch, occasionally over-wrought and melodramatic, yet an absorbing and thought-provoking insight into the consequences of human catastrophe.
Appropriately titled, You Again won't win any prizes for originality but it does deliver just enough girly fun.
It's so reminiscent of the arthouse original you are tempted to say "why bother?" but for those coming new to the story it's a treat and, for my money, punchier and more compelling.
Taken on its own terms the utterly imbecilic Jackass 3D must be judged a success...
Due Date is uproarious fun and comfortably holds its own alongside its Steve Martin forebear.
Stone is so winning in a star-is-born performance that you happily sit back and enjoy.
A cheery, rough-around-the-edges family film about three Rwandan children who travel overland from Rwanda to the 2010 World Cup in Johannesburg.
A daffy but enjoyable action-comedy that assembles some impressive oldie firepower.
A very likeable 3D animation that combines originality and charm with a pleasing, spiky humour.
A riveting, era-defining picture that is guaranteed to make you feel very stupid in comparison and very, very poor.
For a man motivated as much by a craving for excitement as cash, the picture about his life is, ironically, a yawn.
There is nostalgia value in revisiting the character but, unfortunately, the picture plays like a faint echo of the original, inferior in every way. Greed just ain't good anymore.
It's not as bad as it sounds. It's much worse.
For sheer oddity value this creation of filmmaking brothers Edward and Rory McHenry must rank as some kind of collector's item.

The skilful screenplay by Chris Sparling maintains the suspense right up to the will-he or wont-he get out ending, while slipping in some welcome black humour and a quietly effective message about state and corporate ruthlessness.
An empty-headed heist movie which makes no effort to endear us to the slick gangsters or the police pursuing them.
Casts a magical spell by the touching conclusion.
A lively celebration of collective action, even if the male-dominated unions are portrayed as misogynisti stick-in the-muds (although they do come good in the end).
A sparkier and more soul-searching script would have made this a much more satisfying journey.
It is so grimly explicit that I couldn't watch at times but there's a nice twist in the tale.
An intriguing twist livens things up midday way but the mood is almost oppressively melancholy and the plot doesn't stack up.
The plot never picks up steam, there are gaping implausibilities and the characters are achingly dull, with the exception of Billy Zane's hilariously smarmy and sleazy professor.
Based on a cult teen novel by John Marsden, the picture has some arresting set-pieces but never makes much sense (where is the Australian army?) and only generates sporadic tension.

Warrior will help cement Hardy's status as one of our most charismatic and muscular stars after the likes of Bronson and Inception, not forgetting his riveting turn as Ricky Tarr in Tinker, Tailor, while Edgerton makes an implausible character believeable.
A beautifully crafted period piece that could have been made in the 1970s, albeit with the benefit of modern, sophisticated filmmaking techniques.
It's slow but chilling and memorable.
Ultimately, it's as conventional as the romantic-comedies it mocks. Still, fans of the stars should get satisfaction.
Saldana has star quality and action chops but the script is laughable and boring.
It's sluggish in places and too long but has a memorable hero in Hans and remains amusingly straight-faced.
A poor man's Human Traffic.
A big yawn, bereft of drama, surprise or any discernible point.
A well-crafted British horror-thriller that recalls classics like The Wicker Man and Witchfinder General but which ultimately fails to convince or provide a satisfactory climax.
A jaunty remake of the 1985 horror-comedy that gives Farrell his juiciest leading role in years, literally.
Gosling exudes a cool, studied confidence and the scenes of him educating Cal, while displaying his own killer prowess with women, are amongst the most entertaining.
Surprisingly inventive...
Falling between two stalls, the picture fails to qualify as a romantic comedy but lacks the power and depth of a good romantic drama.
A thought-provoking, powerfully acted and resonant exploration of rough justice in the modern world...
A painfully amusing watch.
The Guard, like its unconventional hero, is a true original.

Robert Rodriquez delivers another irritating Spy Kids movie, Spy Kids: All The Time In The World in 4D, with the redundant gimmick of scratch and sniff cards, designed to reveal on-screen aromas. Well, I didn't smell turkey. In fact, I smelt nothing.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The men's relationship is dull and under-explored and the plot is slow, unexciting and silly. Craig is a lot more fun in a tuxedo than a stetson.
A very pleasant surprise.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a bizarre and intriguing tale but Bernie remains essentially unknowable and the picture lacks big laughs.
The devilish nature of Latif's predicament continually intrigues.
A mixture of live-action and animation, it's a competently made but routine adventure...
There's little satisfaction for the audience in this uninspired sword-and-sorcery adventure...
Gosling exudes Steve McQueen-esque cool but there's not enough going on under the bonnets of these characters to justify the laboured, pretentious execution.
A thought-provoking documentary that throws a spotlight on the beleagured newspaper trade and the values traditional journalism help sustain.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The leads have an infectious chemistry and Ally is a refreshingly modern heroine with a nice screwball touch.
It's slow but atmospheric and memorable.
Well cast and acted, with Imelda Staunton as the school matron, the picture is watchable and handsomely made but it's rather weakly plotted and never truly chills.

Rich in atmosphere and brimming with eccentrics, the picture should be a home-run for Robinson who has plenty of opportunities to indulge in Withnail-style insanity but the picture never quite takes off.
Children will undoubtedly enjoy it but I suspect this animated gift is merely for Christmas and not for life.
Arrestingly shot in natural light, with no soundtrack, the moors have never seemed more alien or bleak and this does stay with you but at over two hours long it's rather hard work.
You certainly can't accuse Spielberg and his screenwriter collaborators Richard Curtis and Lee Hall of not trying.
The idea is sweet enough, recalling Africa United, but the execution is painfully amateur. Improbable, hackneyed and very dull.
There's a certain absurdity, as well as outlandishness, to Childers' tale that Marc Forster's film, starring Gerard Butler, never quite shakes off.
A waste of time.
It's no Trading Places but Tower Heist is a fun, snappy and well-played caper...
I was disappointed at the end to realize the picture was fiction not fact but perhaps that's a tribute to the authenticity writer-director Tate Taylor achieves in this beautifully realized picture.
It's hard to imagine how Belgian creator Herge would be anything other than thrilled.
Atmospheric and beautifully shot but ultimately empty and meaningless...
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Sluggish, witless and desperately twee.
A chilling, meticulously researched thriller...
A pretentious and perfectly daft film that manages to combine absurdity with tedium.
It's more silly than scary with not enough plot and surprise but the cast are good.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The characterization is too thin but the cast do fine work and the drama grips.

A delightful exercise in wish-fulfillment, the picture is one of the most unashamedly romantic of Allen's career - if not the most - with hardly a trace of his cynical, caustic and darkly ironic take on the world.
With its powerful performances, good twists and fast-pacing The Debt is a welcome adult thriller...
Sincere but poorly scripted and badly acted by leads Dan Fredenburgh and Doraly Rosa.
A serviceable if familiar premise is executed without thrills and excitement while Lautner doesn't have the necessary edge or charisma to carry the movie.
Some lugubrious preaching aside, this is taut, unpredictable and eerie, with good performances, including from John Goodman as an exasperated FBI agent.
Silly but amiable...
None of it makes much sense, the characters are largely annoying and the underground Martian city is drab and uninviting.
A well-crafted homage to a master filmmaker who, ironically, was accused early in his career of infantilizing cinema but created some of the most memorable elegies to childhood and lost innocence.
Much of the plotting is perfunctory but the slap-stick is fun and Carrey, toning down his usually mugging, shrewdly lets the penguins steal the show.
A taut, nervy guessing game that had me on the edge of my seat.
Not for the sensitive, this is an efficient, well performed thriller that makes a few unconvincing stabs at social commentary.
Sassoon deserves this tribute and there are some interesting social insights.
The picture is a little unpolished - characters get lost, tension slackens off - but Cornish pulls off his preposterous premise with flair.
Made with great sincerity and charm, even if dramatically it meanders rather too purposelessly at times.
First time writer-director Patrick Hughes shows great promise as a genre filmmaker.
Who ever thought we'd care?
A kind of American Pie for young adults, there is much amiable and good-hearted humour here amongst the cruder elements and the strange nether-world of conventions is amusingly captured.
Conjures up a nightmarish quality that I found difficult to shake off.
The storytelling lacks some polish but the picture builds to a powerful, high body-count climax.
The picture aims for Little Miss Sunshine-like laughs and tears but isn't quite funny or dramatic enough although the characters are sympathetic and it's very nicely performed.
If the movies are designed to transport us to inaccessible worlds you can't beat Cave Of Forgotten Dreams...

On paper, the remake may have seemed like a good idea - not least given Brand's own womanising and substance abuse past - but the result is a charmless misfire that puts Brand's movie star ambitions into cold storage.
Packed with incident, spectacular crashes and tragedy, filmed very effectively in 3D.
The plot, is frankly, completely barmy but it's directed with panache and energy by Luc Besson and is good fun for the most part.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Ad√®le Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Ad√®le Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An atmospheric, beautifully photographed but ultimately rather pointless existential Russian drama about two contrasting men stuck together on a deserted Arctic island to record meteorological data.
[A] moving documentary...
The picture is nicely acted, especially by Marion Cotillard as a bored seductress, and it addresses mid-life soul-searching and self-deception with some acuity.
A sweet but strangely low-key affair, not least because of the slight running time.
Suffers from a chronically lazy script, irritating characters and dirth of funny ideas.
The plot proves surprisingly suspenseful as, Agatha Christie-like, the culprit could be anyone.
If you are a fan of atmosphere-led, low-budget horror in the vein of Paranormal Activity then this is a worthy watch.
An infectiously enjoyable adventure that combines great spectacle with human drama and tongue-in-cheek fun with just the right degree of seriousness.
A simpler, more coherent and amusing adventure that is the most fun in the series - and shortest - since the original.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If The Hangover gave you hope for Hollywood - yup, there is some creativity and boldness left - The Hangover Part II sinks it.
It's slightly overlong and its message of "geek empowerment" feels overfamiliar but for fans X-Men: First Class delivers with aplomb.
Based on a novel by Tatiana de Rosney, the picture is superbly acted, especially by 10-year-old Melusine Mayance as Sarah, and tense and distressing in parts.
The picture provides a compelling insight into the mindset required to be one of the "men in black": tough, masochistic and deeply vain.

Director Daniel Monzon's picture - very well acted by the leads - manages to combine extremely clever, unpredictable plotting with plausible but unexpected character development, elevating standard genre fare to something much more substantial.
A fascinating, darkly humorous but ultimately disturbing portrait of troubled genius.
Crude fun.
There's no doubt about it: Harry Potter ends on a high.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's no doubt it could have been much worse. It could have been Transformers 2.
What should be an exciting courtoom thriller with intriguing contemporary parallels plays likes laborious and self-important TV movie.
A crashing bore.
Explores the religious, cultural, social and judicial minefield that is modern Iraq through the story of a divorcing middle-class couple.
It's quite astonishingly amateur and awful.
The chilling and highly informative film shows how perilously close we are to nuclear catastrophe, either via terrorism, Dr Strangelove-style cock-up or simple accident.
There is real depth to the characterizations and friendships. It is so funny because it is all so painfully real.
It's well acted - especially by the underused Craig Parkinson as the resident psycho - but is by turns dull and unpleasant.
The subject matter is thought-provoking and inspiring and the performances from young and old alike are A-grade.
Although it stumbles on the storytelling, drifting rather repetitively around the lives of its haunted protagonists, it's a rewarding, humane picture.
Finding beauty in the banal, the picture is a stirring hymn to humanity that makes the world feel simultaneously small and vast.
It's brisk, puerile fun with added charm thanks to the game cast. A bit like watching your teachers make twits of themselves.
What we're left with is a daft premise and a damaged movie star desperately trying to endear himself to the audience. A bold but doomed effort.
There are moments of tension but it's too long, no one to like and the ending is pointlessly grim.
It is made with consummate craft, contains some exciting set-pieces and the voice work is top-notch.
Shallow without being fun or sexy, the picture is a well-meaning but ponderous bore. The characters are dull, their ruminations tedious and uninvolving and the relationship insights banal.
A colourful, good-hearted romp with some memorable set-pieces and decent lines, crisply directed by David Bowers.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A rambunctious documentary about Irish traveler families and their running feuds resolved through fisticuffs.
The plot has a certain energy but the characters are obnoxious and the gags fall flat.
McConaughey is terrific but the picture is really made by the fierce and unforgettable performance of Tye Sheridan as Ellis.
There's no reason this couldnt be witty or amusing but Almodovars smutty, high-camp approach plays like Airplane with artistic pretensions and none of the laughs.
Is he completely heartless, in some kind of catatonic trauma or just stupid?
The picture's great achievement is the adept balancing of so many characters. It never feels overstuffed and everyone has their moment and purpose while several new heroes are introduced.
The picture is pure hokum and all the more welcome for it.
It's a curio for Davis fans rather than a rewarding watch for people, like me, who knew little about him in the first place.

No great passion is being conjured up on screen, just an exhausted sense of relief that things might not be as bad as all that. Which is what you might say for the film as a whole after all its troubles.
The self-serious tone and absurd plotting is, frankly, criminal.
The picture may be a glorified "war room" re-enactment of the sort shown on television but it's so well done it deserves to be seen on the big screen.
A treat for all ages.
The picture looks lovely and despite keeping us in the dark about Ramunujan's breakthroughs it builds to an effective climax as he finds acceptance in the college's hallowed walls.
Spectacular costumes and impressive special effects can't compensate for the tired story, which never justifies its existence.
It's unsettling and unforgettable.
It's strange, but not in a good way.
It's inoffensive and amusing enough. It just doesn't soar.

It's clear early on that no great raison d'√™tre for a follow up has been alighted on by writer/star Nia Vardalos and the result plays like a rather desperate attempt to recapture the same eccentric charm of the original.
Director Zack Snyder has blown it.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The friendship between predator and prey stands as a powerful rebuke to Donald Trump.

A beefed-up Fiennes gives a sturdy, thoughtful performance, if a touch understated, and it's handsomely mounted by director Kevin Reynolds, best known for action pictures like Robin Hood: Prince Of Thieves and Waterworld.
I was expecting to feel many things watching director Ben Wheatley's adaptation of JG Ballard's novel High-Rise: shock, outrage, disgust, hilarity, exhilaration. What I did not expect was boredom.

Skilfully directed by first-timer Dan Trachtenberg, it's overlong and doesn't sustain the intrigue throughout but an explosion of tension towards the end results in a gripping, if preposterous, finale.
The production values are strong and the young cast engage, including Theo James and Miles Teller. But really, it's enough now.
The story is a little slight and rushed in places but it has (n)oodles of charm and good humour.
The premise is strong enough to sustain interest even though the drama lacks emotional intensity and edge-of-the-seat suspense.
Ultimately, you are tempted to conclude that the film is a bit like Alice's chat show: a vanity project.
It makes you immediately want to re-watch all his work.
It may have a slight televisual air about it but the warbling dame is larger-than-life and weirdly inspirational.
Bad Neighbours 2 is in exuberantly bad taste and the cast give it their all. But the freshness has gone and the plotting is pretty ramshackle.
It's good-humoured, well performed and a couple of the gags are zingers. My 11-year-old son had a blast. It's just spookily inconsequential.
It's mildly amusing and thought-provoking but Moore's cartoonish turn is awkward, making Georgette appear a fool, and ultimately it's all rather pointless.
It's all very familiar.
With low expectations, it's a solid enough adventure with some reasonable action set-pieces. Just don't expect to be shouting from the treetops.
It's not on a par with Thurber's previous comedy hits but it is consistently amusing and well paced with a good blend of human interest and action.
Made with heart and affection, it really is a welcome return for these much loved characters and a merrily mad swansong that will leave you smiling.
It entertains throughout, thanks in part to an endless stream of new animals who help or hinder Max and Duke in their quest to make it back home.
It's a one-joke scenario that raises only the odd wry smile while the thin story struggles to reveal or say anything of significance.
If this is the future of the blockbuster, it's time to batten down the hatches.
Everything is spelt out so blatantly, it's as if the filmmakers assume their audience - mummies - are so brain dead with child rearing they can't be expected to understand anything.
Hiddleston is wholly convincing as the tortured star, performing the songs himself with a satisfyingly deep rumble.
The result is unsubtle, rarely funny and forgettable but McCarthy is a force of nature and a very good comic actress and Bell makes for an appealing foil.
Warcraft, what is it good for? Absolutely nothing.
The stars have to work overtime to compensate for underwritten characters but there are some nice comic moments and the climax is undeniably touching.
These Nice Guys finish last.
It may not be Oscar-worthy but the picture tells Owens' remarkable story effectively and with increasing tension, especially once the action shifts to the Games themselves.
A welcome return to comedy for Hanks, although the humour is wryly absurdist rather than properly funny.
After Once and Begin Again, Irish writer-director John Carney makes it a hat-trick of delightful rites-of-passage musical films with his latest, Sing Street.

Born with special gifts and powers, they whinge endlessly about being different and treated by society with suspicion but it's poor old humans who end up crushed underfoot by their warring ways - and frankly, I've had enough.
For the record, my eight-year-old son gave it five stars.

It's not sharp or funny or scabrous enough to work as a dark comedy and it leaves an uncomfortable taste, in part because Barker never actually broke a story of profound significance. She was the story.

While well made, strongly acted and relatively intriguing the film doesn't have a distinguishing feature to make it a cinematic must see, be that a charismatic star turn, sumptuous locations or thrilling action.

Moore is at his most relaxed and engaging, speaking to people across the social spectrum and building a fascinating picture of a utopian world that could just exist if all these qualities were combined.
Gaping plot holes and plausibility issues render the film ludicrous as does unintentionally (I assume) hilarious dialogue.
It goes on for ever and is like watching paint dry.
Despite an effective early creepiness, the story becomes incoherent and director Jason Zada relies on increasingly redundant shock tactics.
They may be two of the biggest and sexiest stars on the planet but no one wants to watch their romantic travails, not least if we are being asked to take it all seriously.
There isn't enough story to sustain the running time and it lacks howlingly funny set-pieces.
It is a strange mix of intentional and unintentional laughs.
You will either find The Dressmaker a hoot or a perplexing bore, like a shaggy dog story that is not nearly as entertaining as the teller seems to think.

Bar a typically stirring performance from Lawrence, it is all a bit run-of-the-mill; the survival challenges could come from a computer game and lack the grimly compelling dynamic of the child-versus-child Hunger Games themselves.
Fathers And Daughters is a strongly acted but unconvincing drama starring Russell Crowe as a widower struggling to raise his five-year-old daughter Katie in 1989.
As well as being tiresome it does not ring true.

Works best as a character study, observational comedy (there are good jokes at the expense of liberal guilt and property obsession) and, best of all, as a glorious celebration of one of our finest actresses.
A tiresomely talky and self-consciously cerebral French film from director Olivier Assayas.
Overlong, it could be sharper and funnier but hits enough high notes with its infectious joie de vivre.
The picture touches on several pertinent themes including youth versus experience, love and loss and Lily Tomlin deserves awards recognition but it is never quite funny or powerful enough.
It is hard to find the characters' preoccupations anything other than ridiculous, however divine the food looks.
Stelfox is a bore and the picture lacks the energy, comedy and purpose of an American Psycho or The Wolf Of Wall Street.
A delightful and inspiring portrait of a young woman who might just change the world.
Quantum of Solace barely feels like a Bond movie, what with all the staple elements of the franchise stripped bare in an effort to make an even more "realistic" adventure.
I was hoping for a kind of modern day Highlander. Alas, it's closer to a modern day Warlock, the 1989 turkey with Julian Sands.
Plodding and bland with a pair of dead beat buddies of little interest.
It's the best Bond ever.
A lively and amusing sequel to the 2012 hit ...
It is under-plotted and preposterous but quite fun.
Pan is fast-paced and visually impressive.
You may not be uplifted but you will have your eyes opened, especially if you have not seen The Armstrong Lie, Alex Gibney's documentary.
I am sure admirers of the book will feel justice has been done.

It is delightfully animated in the original hand-drawn style and brings a big smile to the face ...

A beautifully crafted yarn that places you right on the rolling decks of the whaling ship Essex as it sails into very stormy waters and encounters a nemesis in the form of a monster-sized sperm whale.

Gere is watchable but constrained by a rushed screenplay that never gives us a proper handle on the man. The potentially intriguing character dynamics fail to splutter into life.
Sacrifices atmosphere and character interest for the intrigues of a murder plot that simply isn't very compelling or consequential.

The story is more relationship drama than wild comedy in the vein of Bridesmaids or Sisters and flits about inconsequentially between the various couples. What holds the attention are the appealing performances.
Triple 9 is not a classic of the genre but it's solidly entertaining.
It's a shaggy dog story with a certain amount of charm but not nearly enough drama.
This is much more boring than a film called Pride And Prejudice And Zombies has any right to be.
Gripping, highly topical entertainment.

If looking at other people's holiday snaps is boring, being stuck on their holiday is even worse, even if your fellow guests are Ralph Fiennes, Tilda Swinton and swoony Belgian actor Matthias Schoenaerts.
It's deliberately puerile, often joyously, sometimes annoyingly, but never dull as the filmmakers have a blast revelling in general superhero movie misbehaviour.
The stunts are impressive. The rest is a wash out.
There really is no reason for the film to exist.

Despite the dark subject matter there's much levity courtesy of Trumbo's droll wit, plus a roll call of Hollywood legends, including Kirk Douglas, Otto Preminger and an ebullient B-movie producer, Frank King, played with gusto by John Goodman.
The picture doesn't have the satirical edge of a Gremlins but it combines a sharp, funny script with some emotional substance.
A sombre military action film that steers clear, at least in Bay terms, of stoking up unwarranted patriotism or exploiting the scenario for cheap sentiment.

Meandering and inconsequential.

The insights are not especially original (the human spirit is strong!) but the execution is astounding.

Compelling.

A wearying trudge thanks to a silly screenplay that finds few laughs and little genuine emotion despite brazen attempts to pull at the heartstrings.
After the 140-minute running time I felt as exhausted as Wolverine.

The film is well put together and Best's talent shines in the archive footage, although you do wonder if he achieved quite as much to deserve all the adulation ...
Ultimately, there is a vacuum where the real investigation should be - into the characters and the human heart.
Interesting but rather unappetising.
Simple, beautifully made and finely acted ...
Well, I know which film I'll be rooting for come Oscar night.
A missed opportunity.
It provides solid enough brickwork for a new franchise and there's no denying this Bat is a mighty relief from the Batfleck.
A complex, fascinating and often highly amusing enigma of a modern woman in a picture that is almost impossible to define; much like its protagonist.
On stage, this would no doubt be powerful stuff but Washington the director has done little to open up the drama and adapt it for the big screen.

Chazelle has taken a big gamble with this homage. It could have turned out horribly twee and sentimental. Instead the picture celebrates a movie-making form from yesteryear with dazzling visual technique and a huge dollop of charm.
Just a soppy romantic drama.

A cleverly conceived one-off that forges its own identity with a new set of characters, a contained storyline and a kind of stripped-down tone and visual approach free of the grandiosity of the series.

Kong: Skull Island is an overblown monster movie that constitutes just shy of two hours of meaningless spectacle.
Too hidebound to the original, never quite evolving an identity or mood of its own while attempts to "modernise" the tale feel a touch too forced and become a little grating.
Proof that you don't need stars or special effects to lure an audience. Just a fresh idea and a twisted imagination.

Delivers broad laughs.

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps this look at the amoral world of lobbying would have been better served as a House Of Cards-style TV drama.
Delivers in terms of horror and suspense, despite a slow build up and some rather pretentious philosophical longueurs.

The cast and production values keep you watching even as the plotting loses its grip.
If the original was a space opera, the sequel is more like a soap opera with complicated and angry familial relationships determining the action.

Her story is told mostly via her letters, read by Tilda Swinton, and it contains astute warnings for the future. But frustratingly there are no contributions from historians or biographers to provide context and analysis.

Three cheers for Nighy who is a hoot and rather touching as an old ham past his sell by date, even if it is ironic that in a film that celebrates female empowerment the most colourful and charming character is a man.

There are a few plot holes and weak motivations exhibited by various characters but the sheer energy on display makes it easy enough to suspend disbelief.

As with all anthologies the nature of the format means some are better than others. And with this many on offer inevitably there are a few clunkers, but they are so short they don't have time to outstay their welcome.

While it won't change the world it certainly deserves to be seen, especially as this is probably Beckinsale's strongest dramatic performance in several years.

The bottom line is that despite a strong opening act The Complex just isn't very scary.
While The Conjuring is incredibly well made there's little we haven't seen before.
You've seen found footage horror and Nazi zombies before, but Frankenstein's Army mashes them together in a way that breathes new life into tired genre conventions.
It doesn't offer easy answers, but for many its unique take on British folklore will prove Wheatley is one of the most fascinating directors currently at work in the UK.

When you see Marvel happily rubbing shoulders with DC or Star Wars fans chatting to Star Trek fans it makes you proud to be a geek.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It gives an insight into the creative process and the drive and passion necessary to produce something you want to share with the world.
It's an unconventional but compelling film as four soldiers find themselves trapped behind enemy lines during an unspecified war.
There are some gory kills and some goofy fun as a huge chainsaw thrusts out of the screen in 3D, but this is a generic by the numbers slasher that squanders TCM's grimy history.
The colour scheme is garish and nausea-inducing but somehow Manborg is endearingly lo-fi DIY entertainment and Kostanski should be applauded for what he's achieved on this minimal budget.
Essential viewing for any fantasy film fans.

movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A contemplative off-beat drama taking a very original look at how society copes with death.
Silly, lightweight, completely unnecessary but surprisingly fun.
Zombie has a vision and you assume in his mind it all adds up to something very dark, deep and meaningful, but that meaning been lost in translation and the film comes across as vague and confused.
Not a truly terrible film, just completely underwhelming and anonymous.
movie_title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Admittedly, the CGI rat isn't great and the energy drops whenever Sheridan or Walliams are offscreen, but kids will love the mix of gross-out comedy with a nice message about the importance of friends, loyalty and believing in yourself.

movie_title: Lamb Of God's As The Palaces Burn (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A rare example of a remake that is as good as, if not better, than the original.

movie_review_blurb: Not much more than a glossy, caffeine-jacked re-do of Rambo.
For those who like their Hong Kong movies to come at them straight from the shoulder ... Fulltime Killer fulfills all the conventions of raw Cantonese gun opera.

movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Movie (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Meyer keeps his camera hopping and the production has a dark, atmospheric sheen that persistently suggest mystery and danger. Not the best of the series, but a suitable farewell.
movie_title: Star Trek VI - The Undiscovered Country (1991)

movie_review_blurb: The film's sole dramatic preoccupations are with broad physical comedy and unrealistically offbeat characterizations; a few moments of nominal pathos are really just structural pauses in the joke series.

The movie displays an almost preternatural disregard for women's feelings - call it Pygmalion, with a heavy accent on the first syllable - but the comedy is so slickly delivered that audiences may be content with chuckling over its polished surface ...
Every one of these dramatic maelstroms manages to appear fresh because Freeman and Tandy somehow manage to come up with new approaches, meting out complementary aspects of their characters.
The ostensible humor here is of the macho one-liner variety, and much of it falls flat.
[A] mess.
